Pawan Kalyan.description: GUNTUR: Stating that they will bulldoze bastions of TDP and YSR Congress, Janasena president Pawan Kalyan promised to grant Rs 5,000 pension to all farmers in the state. He said they will also grant Rs 8,000 crop incentive to farmers soon after coming into power in the next elections. Pawan further said his government would provide six to 10 LPG cylinders free-of-cost to each family every year. and also promised to fill 3 lakh vacancies in the government departments to provide jobs to youth. Addressing a meeting in Guntur on Monday, Pawan said that the future of the state did not mean the future of Lokesh and Jagan but it was the future of the people. “The space on the state’s political stage is not TDP’s and YSRC’s property as youth and women are eager to bring change through Jana Sena.” “TDP had lost moral right to rule the state as chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu had no control over his legislators who indulged in illegal activities,” Pawan said adding that he jumped into the political arena to bring in a change in the lives of commoners. “We supported TDP and BJP in the last elections with a hope to transform the state. Unfortunately, both of them have shattered our dreams,” he said. “Guntur city has been left in a lurch despite located a few kilometres away from the capital city. The entire city has been dug out in the guise of laying underground drainage scheme and left without repair. How shocking it is to see 30 people dying of diarrhoea in a city like Guntur? Is it not the failure of the state government? Opposition leader Jaganmohan Reddy is equally responsible for the tragedy as he never dared to question the government by going to the assembly,” he said. He further said they would construct apartments exclusively for Muslims in the city. He appealed to people to support his candidates Chandrasekhar (Guntur West), Zia-Ur-Rehman (East) and MP candidate Bonaboina Srinivas Yadav in the elections, Pawan said they fielded a BC candidate Srinivasa Yadav whereas TDP and YSRC both have given tickets to their own communities. Satta Matka 2018.description: AGRA: Shyam Vohra, known as 'satta king' of the Taj city, was denied bail by district court of Agra. Vohra, who was arrested by the Agra police in July for his alleged involvement in betting on FIFA World Cup matches. Earlier, in April, Vohra was arrested by the Nodia STF from Greater Noida for placing bets on IPL matches, but he was granted bail. After Vohra’s arrest, Agra police booked him and his known associates including his son Vatsal, wife Rakhi, nephew Prateek, brother-in-law Kaushal and others for their alleged involvement in betting. On Monday, judge Anil Kumar Pundhir rejected Vohra’s bail plea, who was charged for attempt to murder, as he allegedly opened fire on policemen. Further, Vohra was charged for running illegal gambling racket, criminal conspiracy and obstructing policemen from executing their duties. Police are yet to arrest the relatives and associates of Vohra. Several years back, Vohra had gain notoriety for betting on cricket matches. In April, during IPL matches, the gambling racket run by Vohra had deposited Rs 62 lakh in 10 banks, after which police approached banks to freeze the amount. Even during the FIFA World Cup, Vohra collected huge amount of cash through betting. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

It\u2019s now easier to talk about menta.description: At the best of times, mental health is not a topic that lends itself easily to public conversations. The stigma attached to conditions such as depression or anxiety is all too real in India, leaving sufferers despairing of a way out of the darkness. This is where support networks come in, with the offer of a patient and empathetic ear, and (just maybe) the promise of future emotional well-being. Finally, it seems, there’s a window for those who struggle to see the light. Sakshi Virmani reports Hawkers and peddlers swarm the Georgian colonnades of Connaught Place on a busy Sunday evening. Inside Central Park, a group of 15 youngsters huddle together on the dew-drenched grass, unmindful of ardent lovebirds playing peekaboo around them. The session gets underway with an activity in which members are asked to identify a nearby object, something they can relate to. A bespectacled boy picks a bench, someone else chooses a defunct traffic light. At this Offcause meet-up, each of the 15 is being keenly observed by a psychologist, who is helming the hour-long group therapy. Here, you can speak freely about your fears, anxieties and traumas, and, also, share tips on how to get by. The idea is to get everyone talking, to make sure nobody feels left out, by providing a sheltered space and an environment that’s non-judgemental, accommodative and creative. Offcause, for example, lends a hand by encouraging men and women to talk candidly, or to take part in activity-based therapy (painting, dance, improv comedy). More than a few come to listen, some seek succour in the shape of suggestions, yet others draw strength from fellow participants who have emerged from the shadows. “Acknowledging the stigma is the first step, and getting yourself out of the house is another – we self-stigmatise ourselves so much,” claims UK-based Jhilmil Breckenridge, a poet, mental-health activist and founder of Bhor Foundation, an initiative devoted to mental health. Indeed, for the thousands whose days seem perpetually gloomy, an hour or so in the right company might help part the clouds to reveal a ray of sunshine.  LISTENING WITHOUT PREJUDICE Initiatives like Offcause offer a support web for the many overwhelmed by mental health concerns, without the patient having to shell out on a therapist (thus, avoiding the unease of a visit to the psychiatrist). Such collectives comprise individuals whose experiences leave them best suited to help others similarly afflicted. “After I got out of depression, I realised it really helps to talk to somebody who is going through similar issues, as it gives them hope,” admits Mridul Trehan, who credits counseling received by the Delhi Depression Support Group for his recovery. Ujala, a 29-year-old from Jammu, suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and clinical depression. A regular at Offcause meet-ups, Ujala feels that sharing her experiences can be of immense value to fellow sufferers trying to understand the difference between surface and underlying issues. “Personally, I am seeing a psychiatrist and a psychologist for my PTSD and depression, but I love being a part of Offcause — to help others going through various mental disorders,” she says. “You cannot categorise mental illness due to some accident or trigger, it depends on genetics and the way some people’s brains are wired. Some incidents have a ripple effect, they keep playing again and again, which is emotionally consuming,” explains Ujala, who doesn’t just recall incidents, she relives them (like the domestic violence she and her mother have been victims of). For Offcause founder Nikita, it was a causal Instagram update on World Mental Health Day last October that proved the spark. “I asked if people had any stories to share anonymously for the Instagram page I wanted to launch, (and) the response was great – it was surprising to see my closest friends talking about issues they would have never discussed with me on the rare occasions we would meet,” reveals Nikita, who, having left her job just three months earlier, was somewhat at her wit’s end. So, a page was created and the conversations continued. In less than a month, Offcause had its first informal group therapy session. Since then, it has been hosting meet-ups on the third Saturday of every month in Delhi, Gurgaon and Mumbai.  STRIKING THE RIGHT NOTE At an upmarket gastropub in South Delhi, a group of musicians are sharing a laugh over pints of draught beer. They form part of support group Good Vibration, initially launched to discuss problems affecting young musicians, and anybody associated with the industry. Now, anyone can join in, in the monthly meets. Founder Rithika Nayan, a music teacher and certified life coach, commences by talking about anxiety. Soon, the discussion touches on panic attacks, and how best to deal with them. “Scream!” suggests one. “Take a nap!” recommends another, a quick-fix that has everyone nodding in unison. “We millennials are looking for external validation all the time. Blowing things out of proportion in our heads, overthinking and suppressing emotions leads to extreme outbursts. We are never taught how to deal with our emotions intelligently,” explains Rithika to an audience of 12, all absorbed. “Keeping a gratitude journal really helps — counting the small blessings makes a difference,” she offers. According to a 2015-16 survey by Bangalore-based National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences (NIMHANS), 13.7% of India’s general population suffers from a mental ailment. While 150 million Indians are in urgent need of mental health intervention, only 30 million have access to such care. And, according to WHO (World Health Organisation) projections, by 2020 approximately 20% of Indians would be beset by some form of mental illness. Yet, to many in India, mental health still comes with plenty of baggage, and potential loss of face in front of peers. The older generation is reluctant to talk about it and the young think it’s a fad, believes psychologist Dr Ritu Dangwal. She advocates an organised support network. “Support groups are essentially reassurance and reinforcements, more like stopgap arrangements. The groups need to realise that if a person needs extra help, they must guide them to psychiatrists,” she insists. “In India, poor people don’t have the bandwidth to access even basic medical care. But it is heartening to know at least the younger generation is reaching out and saying it’s okay to talk about it.” Dr Dangwal does, however, advise caution. “The tricky part is when everyone starts giving advice. It’s encouraging to have support groups but only to a point — they can address problems at the surface.”  CARE FOR THE CAREGIVERS On a Saturday afternoon last month, a support group of caregivers assembled to discuss family and relationships at Khoj Studios, in the bylanes of Delhi’s Khirki Extension. The Listening Circles provide solace and support not just for those undergoing mental distress, but also for their caregivers, who could be a spouse, parents or children. This support network is moderated by Namarita Kathait, a commissioning editor with a publishing house, and Jhilmil Breckenridge. “We wanted to start a support group that is non-hierarchal, and to get people together in a safe space to have a discourse on mental health,” tells Namarita, 25, who inadvertently became a caregiver for her mother when she was diagnosed with schizophrenia. “I was labelled as the sad girl in school because I did not know how to express what I was going through,” she says, speaking for the many who choose to remain silent. For Jhilmil, it’s important that guidance or advice is not pushed against anyone’s wishes. “People are already vulnerable, we don’t want to force things like meditation and spirituality on them,” she stresses. The next step, says Namarita, is to build ‘listening circles’ with those who have attended the sessions, and to create support groups in their own localities, in colleges and hostels, and among the wider community. “Our ethos is very clear – we are here to listen and we keep it as liberal as possible,” she maintains. “People have the right to speak and not speak, to walk in at any point they want.”  YOU’RE NOT ALONE Then there are youngsters striving to cope with parents who have been diagnosed with a mental illness. It’s this bracket that an upcoming support group network is looking to rally around. Behind the group is Divya Dureja, a counseling psychologist, LGBT activist and TEDx speaker. “If your parent experiences mental illness, it is normal for you to have all kinds of different feelings,” she reasons. “You might not understand why your parents act the way they do. It might be hard to know how to understand your parent, or what to do for them.” Divya believes volunteer caregivers need to be empowered as a first line of defence. “I’ve been building frameworks of mental health support groups that don’t seem to exist in our country,” she explained. “Over the past year, I’ve interacted with over 400 students, primarily studying psychology, at panels, summits and workshops, and (also) those individuals who are looking for resources that are empowering to their mental health.” For, psychological well-being is as critical for the ones who deliver care as for those who receive it. And sanctuary can also be found online. On It’s Ok To Talk, the young can share their innermost thoughts through blogs, poetry, video stories, artwork, even audio recordings. But not only the young. Among the personal accounts on the website is a 58-year-old Gurgaon man’s cry from the heart: ‘Today my heart is brimming painfully with hurt feelings and emotions and there is no one here to share these feelings with or to have a shoulder to cry on little… I have been facing problems linked with depression, schizophrenia and what not since ages now – and with me all my family too…’ Proof that age doesn’t discriminate against the despondent of spirit. It’s Ok To Talk reaches out via digital, social media and on-ground activities, which could include public talks, arts-based events and youth leadership programmes. “Anyone can share stories, of lived experiences of mental health and well-being, and the same will have a tremendous impact on those who may be struggling themselves, and help them realise that they are not alone,” informs Sweta Pal, a member of the Delhi team. “By sharing your own story, you can help inspire other young people that mental health does not need to be shrouded in silence, and it’s ok to talk about it.” Happily, it is becoming easier to talk about mental health, aided by get-togethers that are informal and intimate. And while the fragmented nature of the space means there will always be patients who slip through the cracks, still folks are turning to a growing number of support networks, offering as these do more than a glimmer of hope to the unmoored, the lonely and the vulnerable of India. FIR filed in Gurugram metro station hara.description: GURUGRAM: An FIR has been lodged against an unidentified man for stalking and sexually harassing a 29-year-old woman executive at Huda City Centre metro station on Friday. TOI reported about the case on Tuesday. Police have registered a complaint under IPC sections 354A (sexual harassment) and 506 (criminal intimidation). According to ACP crime, Shamsher Singh, the woman, who is yet to file a written complaint, has been requested to record a statement. “We have registered a complaint against an unidentified man and we are currently trying to identify and locate the accused. We are looking at the CCTV feed from the spot,” said Singh. On Friday night, the woman was allegedly harassed by a man in his 20s when she was walking towards the exit at the Huda City Centre metro station. She told TOI that the man stood in front of her and masturbated, and when she confronted him and slapped him, he screamed at her. She further said no one had come to her rescue. The woman had written to Gurugram Police on Facebook Messenger on Friday itself with details of the incident. However, when she did not get a response till Monday, she took to Twitter to share her ordeal. She also reached out to DMRC and identified the accused in the CCTV feeds provided by them on Sunday. “I want to file a complaint and pursue this case because it is time we start speaking about the need for safe spaces for women,” she told TOI. “But at the same time, I am scared about my own safety.” Police’s delayed response has only made those apprehensions worse. The woman is originally a resident of Delhi but moved to Gurugram as she works there. The incident, she says, may have a disruptive effect on her life as she fears she might now be forced to move back to Delhi. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Tejasvi Surya.description: BENGALURU: From a boy who was groomed by late Union minister H N Ananth Kumar and Tejaswini Ananth Kumar to becoming the challenge to the family’s control over Bengaluru South segment, Tejasvi Surya has come a long way.While expressing his gratitude to Kumar and his family, Surya says he is a stark example of the BJP’s intent to infuse young and new blood. You were a surprise choice for Bengaluru South. Did you expect this development?While I had feelers that there was something like this going around, I was quite happily savouring pani puri with my friends. To be honest I was overwhelmed and started tweeting about this. I only feel gratitude towards the party, which is facing a crucial election and has decided to take risk by fielding a youngster in such a prestigious seat. At 28, will you be able to fill the shoes of Kumar?Filling the shoes of Ananth Kumar is a far fetched thing for he was so gigantic. I only pray to God to give me strength, sincerity and earnestness to honestly work for the people of this constituency so that one day in the eyes of the people I can match up to Kumar’s contribution to the constituency. On lack of political experience, I have a well oiled party organisational machinery to support me with senior leaders there to hand hold me. So what is this election going to be for you?Primarily it is an election for PM Narendra Modi’s aspirational India. It is about the promise of a new and young India and I am just an ambassador of the message of this new India. It is a reflection of party and Modi’s inclination of bringing in young blood. Tejaswini not getting the ticket is quite sensitive...Yes it is sensitive but even during her talk with the Karyakartas she told them that the it was time to show maturity. She has given her full support to me. But what is your personal opinion about Tejaswini missing the ticket?When her name was first finalised by the state leadership, it must be March 11, I was the first to extend my support to her and remember posting on social media that she was the most deserving candidate and a good choice from the constituency. But the party decided to field an ordinary karyakarta like me. It is a decision taken by big people and I am just a foot soldier obeying their diktat. I have always supported Tejaswini ma’am and was literally groomed by that family. I have no reason for acrimony. Statements by Karti Chidamabaram suggest that you are the Schutzstaffel of BJP, or the infamous SS of the Nazi Germany... Your tweets also suggest that your idealogical beliefs are in conflict with the “Sab Ka Saath Sab Ka Vikas” For Karti Chidambaram and others I will reply back to them in their own coin. The idealogical inclinations are not an issue for this election. The issue for the election today, is PM Modi’s promise of a new and superpower India. My only concern as on today is to ensure that Bangalore South elects the BJP with a massive margin so that we will strengthen Modi hands. Rest is immaterial. Is age an advantage or do you require time to project yourself as a leader?That the party leadership has reposed faith in me speaks for itself and the least minimum I can do is to live up to it and say I am capable enough as on today to take on these challenges. You must rise to the occasion and I will rise to it. On dynasty politics, considering you are a nephew of a sitting BJP MLA and PM Modi has gone on the offensive against the Congress on the issue of “Naamdar”...My candidature and my role and activity in politics has no connection to my uncle’s political life. I have an identity of my own and have worked very hard over years. My aspirations precedes his elections. If the party leadership thought I was a rise to another dynast, they would not have considered me at all. Lok Sabha Elections in Tamil Nadu.description: NEW DELHI: Tamil Nadu goes to polls in the second phase of the seven-phase elections. Elections to 39 parliamentary seats will take place on April 18 in a single-phase polling. Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesTOP CONTENDERSThe four-cornered contest features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). This time the elections are taking place sans the Dravidian stalwarts M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa. AIADMK chief Jayalalithaa passed away in December 2016 while Karunanidhi died in August 2018. While the DMK is contesting on 20 seats, the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesHOW MANY SEATS?Tamil Nadu has 39 Lok Sabha seats and one in neighbouring Puducherry. Here is the list of constituencies: Arakkonam, Arani, Chennai Central, Chennai North, Chennai South, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Erode, Kallakurichi, Kancheepuram(SC), Kanyakumari, Karur, Krishnagiri, Madurai, Mayiladuthurai, Nagapattinam(SC), Namakkal Nilgiris(SC), Perambalur, Pollachi, Ramanathapuram, Salem, Sivaganga, Sriperumbudur, Tenkasi(SC), Thanjavur, Theni, Thiruvallur(SC), Thoothukudi, Tiruchirapalli, Tirunelveli, Tiruppur, Tiruvannamalai, Vellore, Villupuram(SC), Virudhunagar, Puducherry(Union Territory) KEY CONSTITUENCIESThe key constutuencies include Sivaganga, Chennai South, Chennai North, Chennai Central, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Kanyakumari, Karur, Thoothukudi , Nilgiris(SC), Trichy, Vellore amd Arani. Here is a list of contituencies with prominent candiadates or clashes. Tejashwi Yadav.description: PATNA/ BHAGALPUR: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in Bihar legislative assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav kicked off the Lok Sabha election campaign on Monday by addressing public meetings at Gaya, Banka and Bhagalpur in support of the Mahagathbandhan candidates. Close aides of Tejashwi said he is expected to address around 200 election meetings across the state over the next two months. “Tejashwi is the face of RJD and the star campaigner of Mahagathbandhan. He will be canvassing for candidates of all the Mahagathbandhan constituents — RJD, Congress, RLSP, HAM(S) and VIP. Thus, he will be addressing three to four election meetings every day,” Tejashwi’s political adviser Sanjay Yadav told TOI on Monday. Canvassing for RJD candidate Shailesh Kumar alias Bulo Mandal from Bhagalpur, Tejashwi came down heavily on NDA governments at the Centre and in state. He accused PM Narendra Modi of making false promises and propaganda to win the 2014 general election. “It won’t be repeated in the ensuing Lok Sabha elections,” Tejashwi said while raising questions about employment scenario and issues of Vijay Malaya, Nirav Modi, Mehul Chowksi and others who fled the country after swindling money from banks in India. Criticizing Nitish for snapping ties with RJD in 2017, Tejashwi said there was acute shortage of fertilizers, while the health services were also in a poor state. He accused deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi of protecting those involved in the multi-crore Srijan scam in Bhagalpur and some other districts. Urging the audience to vote for the RJD candidate, Tejashwi said the Bhagalpur voters had showed a mirror to Modi by voting for RJD in 2014. “They should do the same this election as the NDA government stands exposed,” he said. Political observers feel Tejashwi has become a good orator, especially after coming out of power in July 2017 when CM Nitish Kumar snapped ties with RJD-led Mahagathbandhan and rejoined BJP-led NDA. “Though not as good as his father in terms of having a rustic touch, Tejashwi is a good orator in terms of eloquence,” said DM Diwakar, political observer and professor at AN Sinha Institute of Social Studies. DLF-3 society protests as water supply r.description: GURUGRAM: Around 60 residents of a housing society in DLF-3 staged a protest at the developer’s office in DLF-1 on Monday demanding resumption of water supply. The area has received no water for the past few days, residents said. Those living in other areas, including DLF-1, 2 and 3 and nearby areas, too complained that they were receiving little to no water. The developer has stated that it will take four more days to restore supply. On Sunday evening, residents of Pink Town House society also filed a police complaint at DLF-3 police station. “We came to know that water is being supplied to other DLF-3 areas but not to us. We are being denied of basic amenities,” said Ritu Naresh, general secretary, RWA, Pink Town House. Over the weekend, residents of DLF-1, 2 and 3, MG Road and sector 43 and 27 had no water because of leakage in a pipeline at Signature Towers junction.Though officials said supply resumed by around 10am on Sunday, residents said they have not yet received water and are dependent on water tankers. “We snapped supply completely for 26 hours to fix the issue. If residents are still suffering from water issues, they should contact their developer,” GMDA executive engineer Sandeep Dahiya said. “Though we received water around 4pm on Sunday, the water pressure is low. It will take another four days for us to provide water,” DLF executive director Shekhar Basu said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

To ease commute, GMDA plans traffic ligh.description: GURUGRAM: In order to ease traffic woes at two of the city’s busiest junctions, Hero Honda Chowk and MDI Chowk, GMDA has invited bids for the installation of traffic lights at these places. However, with two flyovers being recently developed at these intersections, the need for traffic lights raises a question over the administration’s planning at the initial stage. At Hero Honda Chowk, an underpass and a flyover, built at a cost of Rs 138 crore, have eased problems for long-route traffic. “The traffic is smooth while going to or coming from Manesar, but taking a turn towards Sector 10 under the flyover is still cumbersome due to merging vehicles and non-availability of signals,” said Aman Chawla, a city resident. Traffic experts say while the underpass and the flyover have helped in reducing congestion, there are still issues at Hero Honda Chowk due to the movement of vehicles in multiple directions. “As per my understanding, the traffic lights are being installed to streamline the traffic at the junction, which still sees some haphazard movement,” said Sewa Ram of School of Planning and Architecture. The situation is worst at MDI Chowk. According to MCG sources, the original plan was to build a flyover for traffic coming from Atul Katria Chowk and going towards Signature Towers. However, the plan was later tweaked and the flyover was instead built for the traffic coming from Sukhrali and going towards Atul Kataria Chowk. The last-minute changes at the junction have made the situation worse, causing the need for a traffic signal at the junction. “A study showed that maximum traffic flows from Atul Kataria Chowk towards Signature Towers. This is because a large number of people from Old Gurugram coming towards New Gurugram use Atul Kataria Chowk and MDI Chowk. That was the reason why it was decided to build the flyover in that direction but later on, on the instruction of some bureaucrats, the direction was changed,” said a senior MCG official. Despite repeated attempts, GMDA’s mobility chief RK Gandhi could not be contacted. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Haryana kicks off prepaid power meter pr.description: JIND: The electricity department of Haryana has started installing smart prepaid meters in four out of 22 districts as a pilot project and later entire state will be covered, Shatrujeet Kapur, chairman-cum-managing director (CMD) of the department has said. The state government introduced prepaid smart meters, on the lines of prepaid mobile phones, in view of the hefty outstanding of the electricity department on consumers and to streamline consumption of power. A smart meter costs Rs 6,000, which would be provided free of cost to the consumers, said an official. Kapur said the department has bought 10 lakh smart meters for the four districts of Gurugram, Faridabad, Panchkula and Panipat, and the work to install these meters have already started. "After installation of these meters, line loss of power would decrease and consumers would be able to get power on prepaid and postpaid basis. Then people would be able to recharge their meters according to their requirement," he said. The CMD said that the process for calling a tender to purchase 15 lakh meters for the next phase has been initiated and Jind would be covered in that phase. Last year, Jind district was the biggest defaulter of power bills worth Rs 1,500 crore, of which Rs 1,000 crore has now been settled under the government scheme and Rs 500 crore is yet to be recovered from this district. Once the smart meters are installed, there would be no issue of pending bills, as the department would get the payment in advance. As per current practice, the bills are generated after two months and it takes another month to recover the billed amount. Pending bills are a huge issue for the department. Talking to TOI, V P Thakral, the XEN monitoring Dakshin Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam (DHBVN), said that an amount of Rs 3,400 crore is outstanding on the consumers of 12 districts of the state and around Rs 2,500 crore should be pending of the Uttar Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam, which covers 10 districts. "After installing these meters, the bill outstanding issue would vanished completely, as it would be disconnected if not recharged in advance," he said. The new concept would work on the lines of a prepaid mobile phone, as one would require to recharge to avail the facility and the department would not need to send an employee for taking meter readings, he noted. BJP List 2019 Tamilnadu.description: CHENNAI: The BJP's Tamil Nadu candidates list announced on Thursday was on expected lines, with Union minister Pon Radhakrishnan being fielded from Kanyakumari, state chief Tamilisai Soundararajan in Tuticorin, national secretary H Raja in Sivaganga, C P Radhakrishnan in Coimbatore and vice-president Nainar Nagendran in Ramanathapuram. While Pon Radhakrishnan and Raja will fight Congress, which is yet to name candidates for its nine seats in DMK alliance, Tamilisai will cross swords with DMK heavyweight Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. H Raja to contest from Sivaganga for third timeH Raja is contesting from Sivaganga for the third time. In 2014, he came third with 1.33 lakh votes, while in 1999, he came second. It will be a keenly fought battle between Tamilisai and DMK’s state women wing secretary and Rajya Sabha MP K Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. Though Tamilisai initially preferred to contest from Chennai South, which has a sizeable votebank for the party, she finally settled for Tuticorin. AIADMK was keen on retaining south Chennai for sitting MP, J Jayavardhan, son of fisheries minister D Jayakumar. Former TN BJP chief Radhakrishnan will face CPM’s P R Natarajan in Coimbatore. This is the fifth time that Radhakrishnan has been fielded in Coimbatore, a BJP stronghold. While he won two consecutive Lok Sabha elections in 1998 and 1999, he was defeated in the 2004 and 2014 polls. Nainar Nagendran has been pitted against DMK’s IUML candidate K Nawaz Kani. While the party made a quick decision on candidates for four constituencies, Ramanathapuram delayed matters considering the keen contest for the seat among some senior leaders. Nine held for betting during India-Pak W.description: KAITHAL: The police arrested nine persons from Kaithal late on Sunday night for indulging in betting during the India-Pakistan cricket World Cup match, said an official on Monday. The crime investigation agency (CIA) also seized Rs 2.60 lakh in cash, 17 mobiles phones and one television set during the operation. The accused have been identified as Aakash, Deep, Saurabh, Deepak, Maanik, Sandeep, Deepak, Chandan and Aashu -- all hailing from Kaithal district. CIA-1 in-charge Ramesh Chander said they had received information that some persons were betting on India-Pakistan match at a private office on Dhand Road. “A team was formed that raided the spot and nabbed the accused red handed,” he added. Gurugram: As squatters take over green b.description: GURUGRAM: MCG, responding to persistent complaints from residents of Emerald Estate in Sector 65 that culminated in a tweet by a resident on Tuesday, took immediate action to remove illegal encroachments by vendors and kiosks in the green belt along Golf Course Road (extension), removing them all. Emerald Estate residents have been complaining to MCG for months that encroachers were setting up illegal shops on the green belt in their neighbourhood — where they have been planting trees to increase green cover — eating away the green belt and compromising the safety and security of hundreds of families living in condominiums on the stretch. The complainants said they have pleaded with MCG officials to take immediate action against the encroachers, before the green zone turned into an illegal vending zone. MCG officials acknowledged that the encroachments have not only destroyed the green space, but also deprived pedestrians of space. Roadside parking is another problem, which they said causes huge traffic jams on the stretch during peak hours. A senior MCG official told TOI that many illegal shops, eateries and liquor vends have come up on the road between sectors 62 and 65, which have spoiled the development plan of the authorities, adding that after Tuesday’s tweet by a resident, they decided to take immediate action, and sent over a team at around 2pm, who removed all encroachments. “Encroachments on SPR have given rise to security concerns in the area and made the area accident-prone,” said Abhay Singh, a resident of Emerald Estate, whose tweet precipitated Tuesday’s anti-encroachment drive. He added, “We’re happy to see prompt action by the MCG team in response to my tweet on encroachments on the green belt in Sector 65. I hope such violations don’t get repeated. We have plans to restart our plantation drive in the belt adjacent to our society.” Shwetabh Goel said in the past six months, encroachment by roadside ven-dors around their society has increased. “We’ve on several occasions alerted both MCG and HSVP about this, but so far, they hadn’t extended any help. Not only this, street lights near our society are not functional, which, along with these encroachments, are a security risk. There have been some incidents in the past,” he said. Another resident, Pratik Prakash, said, “MCG was prompt enough to act on people’s concern in this case. With the illicit shops now removed, we can resume our plantation drive.” But he added, “MCG needs to keep a tab on this area as these illegal vendors may return soon.” Additional municipal commissioner Y S Gupta said, “On the strict instructions of newly appointed commissioner Vinay Singh, regarding removal of illegal encroachments, the MCG team acted promptly and cleared the encroachment in Sector 65. There were complaints by residents in this regard.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Haryana farmers contest water at tail-en.description: TETRI/NINDANA/KHERI (ROHTAK): While chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar and agriculture minister Om Prakash Dhankar leave no opportunity to claim that irrigation water is reaching canal tail-ends, reality appears to be different. Among the farmers who suffer due to non-availability of water at tail end are those from Meham Chaubishi's Nindana, Khattar's native village. While the Meham Minor canal was flowing in full glory on June 16 when this correspondent visited the spot, farmers in villages of Tetri, Kheri and Nindana were using diesal-run tubewell to irrigate their land as the canal by side of their field was lying dry. Talking to TOI, Ramesh Kumar, an aged farmer from Nindana village sitting inside the parched canal at tail-end said that in last five years, not even a drop of water has been seen. "The BJP government makes hollow claim of providing water to tail-end fields from public stages in urban areas to grab the imagination of voters by talking about transforming the lives of farmers. But the reality for farmers like us remains unchanged. The situation is only turning from bad to worse," Kumar added. Holding district irrigation department responsible for the worrisome situation of tail end farmers, 60-year-old farmer said, "We keep suffering at tail end with parched land while farmers in front areas of the canal enjoy stolen water by bribing the officials and using political pressure," he added. Bhoop Singh of Kheri village, who has his two acres at tail-end of Meham minor branch, said that he had heard that farmers commit suicide due to agriculture crisis and he could understand why. "What should we do with dry land. There is no money to spend on diesel-run tubewells. The expense on one acre get multiplied three times. No money to spend on education of kids. No government official or representative is ready to listen to our woes. They dub us liars when we go to tell them non-availability of water at tail end," Singh added. Sandeep Kumar, a young farmer from Nindana village who also has field at Meham Minor tail-end, told TOI that he had complained to irrigation department office and new Rohtak MP Arvind Sharma of water theft from the branch and how they remained deprived of their share of water, but action was still awaited. Rohtak executive engineer (irrigation department) Ram Niwas said that against the demand of 1,875 cusecs, they get only 1450 cusecs water and "farmers at tail-end were bound to suffer". On government claim of providing water till canal ends, he said, "The day gap (between supply and demand) is met, the issue will be resolved." Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

BSP List 2019 UP.description: LUCKNOW: The BSP on Friday announced its first list of 11 candidates for the Lok Sabha elections 2019, fielding JD(S) turncoat Kunwar Danish Ali from Amroha. Ali, who was general secretary of the Janata Dal-Secular, quit the party and joined the Bahujan Samaj Party only last week. The BSP also declared Haji Fazulrahman its nominee from Saharanpur, Malook Nagar from Bijnore and Girish Chandra from Nagina, a party release said. Hazi Mohammad Yakoob has been fielded from Meerut, Satbeer Nagar from Gautam Buddh Nagar, Yogesh Verma from Bulandshahr, Ajit Baliyan from Aligarh, Manoj Kumar Soni from Agra, Rajveer Singh from Fatehpur Sikri and Ruchi Veera from Aonla. Mayawati's BSP is contesting 38 of the 80 Lok Sabha constituencies in Uttar Pradesh under the seat-sharing arrangement with Samajwadi Party and the Rashtriya Lok Dal. Maharashtra Lok Sabha Constituencies.description: MUMBAI: Maharashtra, which has 48 parliamentary constituencies, will go to polls in four phases, starting April 11. In 2009 and 2014, Lok Sabha elections were held in three phases in Maharashtra On April 11, seven constituencies in Maharashtra’s Vidarbha region will go to polls - Nagpur, Wardha, Yavatmal-Washim, and the naxal-affected areas of Gadchiroli and Chandrapur. In the second phase on April 18, 10 constituencies - including three constituencies in Vidarbha, six in Marathwada and Solapur in western Maharashtra - go to elections. The third phase, on April 23, of polling will be held in Pune, Baramati, Jalgaon, Jalna, Aurangabad, Raigad and Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg, Sangli, Satara and Kolhapur. In the final phase on April 29, all six constituencies in Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Palghar and Bhiwandi will go to polls among the total 17 seats in the state. KEY CONSTITUENCIESAmong the key constituencies are Baramati and Nagpur featuring high-profile candidates such as Supriya Sule and Nitin Gadkari. Then there is Ahmednagar from where Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, is contesting. Other important constituencies are Jalna, Chandrapur, Dhule, Beed, Sangli, Mumbai North Central, Mumbai North and Baramati.    CONSTITUENCIES CONTENDERS   Chandrapur Union MoS Hansraj Ahir (BJP); Suresh Dhanorkar (Congress)   Baramati Kanchan Kul (BJP); Supriya Sule (Congress)   Jalna State BJP chief Raosaheb Danve BJP; Vilas Keshavrao Autade (Congress)   Akola Sanjay Dhotre (BJP); Hidayat Patel (Congress)   Bhiwandi Kapil Patil(BJP); Suresh Kashinath Taware (Congress)    Nagpur Union minister Nitin Gadkari (BJP)   Ahmednagar Sujay Vikhe Patil (BJP)   Dhule Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre (BJP)    Beed Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter Pritam (BJP); Bajrang Sonawane (NCP)   Sangli Sitting MP Sanjay Patil (BJP)    Mumbai North Central Poonam Mahajan (BJP)    Aurangabad Subhash Zambad (Congress)   Gadchiroli Ashok Nete (BJP)   Mumbai North Gopal Shetty (BJP)    Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

\nFemale riders from NCR take on Delhi r.description: On Sunday morning, about 20 women from across Delhi-NCR put on their riding boots, jackets, and helmets; got on their mean machines, and rode the cruisers for 40km across Lutyen's Delhi and the Aravalli trails of Gurgaon. The occasion was the International Women's Day Ride organized by the Women's International Motorcycling Association (WIMA), which had women, not just from WIMA, but also first-timers and amateurs. They started at the break of dawn from Janpath and rode across Lutyen’s Delhi, Hauz Khas, and Chhatarpur before entering Gurgaon through the Aravalli trails and ending their ride at a dhaba on the Gurgaon-Faridabad Road.  Zooming through Delhi: 20 women from NCR rode bikes for 40km across Lutyen's Delhi and the Aravalli trails of Gurgaon Vidhi Malla, National President of WIMA, led the ride and said that this was an occasion to spread the message that biking is not just a male domain but open to everyone with passion. "We thought of using the Women's Day as an occasion to get the entire female biking community of Delhi together. We had 20 girls riding together and it was great because it included everyone from veterans to girls who were doing a long ride for the first time," she said. The riders from Janpath to Gurgaon, taking a back trail instead of the usual roads that lead into Gurgaon. "We took a more scenic route that is not very commonly used by bikers, which meant there was a little off-roading involved too. It was fantastic," said Vidhi.  Vidhi Malla  The riders found the experience quite fun and also said that such rides are essential to put a spotlight on female bikers from NCR. Niharika Singh Dalal, a rescue diver from Delhi, said, "I think events like these promote riding for women because you see women coming together as a team here. You see community building, where women encourage each other and improve each other's skills and that's always great."  The ride was organised to gather female bikers using Women's Day as the occasion 01:36Female riders from NCR take on Delhi roads ahead of Women's DayDownload The Times of India News App for Latest City .

MA student attacked by three bikers, rob.description: GURUGRAM: Three bike-borne youths robbed a 25-year-old man of his gold ring and cash near sector 4/7 Chowk on Saturday morning. The complainant — Ram Prakash — told police that the incident happened when he was on his way to the bus stand. “I am an MA student and was heading to Panipat for my examination. I left my home in Sector 7 around 4.40am for the bus stand. When I reached near the sector 4/7 chowk, three bikers blocked my way, thrashed me and snatched my wallet and gold ring. As the exam was important for me, I left for Panipat and filed a complaint after returning to Gurugram the next day,” Prakash said. An FIR has been registered against the trio under sections 379-A (snatching), 34 (common intention) of the IPC at Sector 9 A police station on Sunday. “We are trying to recover the CCTV footage of the area. We will arrest them as soon as they are identified,” said inspector Basant Chauhan, SHO of Sector 9A police station. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Congress mulls bigger roles for Selja, H.description: CHANDIGARH: In yet another attempt to broker peace among the warring Congress leaders and to salvage the situation emerging out of crushing defeat in the parliamentary elections, the Congress high command is expected to bring in former Union minister Kumari Selja and former CM Bhupinder Singh Hooda on the forefront for the assembly polls. Sources said the party is seriously considering the move despite the fact that both of Selja and Hooda lost the recent elections from Ambala and Sonipat, respectively. Party sources said Selja could be a replacement for Ashok Tanwar, who also lost from Sirsa parliamentary seat. Hooda could be made CLP chief as well as the chairman of the coordination committee. Congress Haryana affairs in-charge Ghulam Nabi Azad has proposed this formula to the party high command, sources said. The final nod has to come from AICC president Rahul Gandhi. Sources said the picture will be clear in Haryana once Rahul takes a final decision about his own resignation as party chief. The Congress suffered a humiliating defeat as it lost all the 10 constituencies to the BJP, including Rohtak and Sonipat constituencies which were considered to be its safest bets in the state. Hooda's son Deepender failed to retain the family bastion of Rohtak. Afterwards, the rift among the leaders intensified as was evident during the meeting of coordination committee wherein state Congress chief Tanwar was targeted. Hooda group had sought removal of Tanwar as the state president and Kiran Choudhary as CLP leader. The entire episode had ended with an embarrassment when Tanwar allegedly abused Hooda aide and MLA Jai Tirath Dahiya, party insiders claimed. Notably, assembly elections in Haryana are just three months away. Besides making a comeback on the lines of Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Rajasthan, Hooda faces the challenge of increasing the seat count in the assembly. AP BJP List 2019.description: NEW DELHI: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), on Thursday, announced its first candidate list for the Lok Sabha elections 2019 that includes 184 candidates. The party has named two candidates from Andhra Pradesh in the first list. Kanna Lakshminarayana will contest from Narasaraopet Lok Sabha constituency while D Purandeshwari will contest from the Visakhapatnam seat. Andhra Pradesh will go to polls in a single phase on April 11. BJP's Lok Sabha first full list The Lok Sabha elections will be held in seven phases from April 11 to May 19, 2019. The counting of the votes has been scheduled for May 23. The first phase will be held on April 11, second on April 18, third on April 23 and fourth on April 29, fifth on May 6, sixth on May 12 and seventh phase on May 19. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will contest from Varanasi constituency, while BJP president Amit Shah will fight from Gandhinagar in place of L K Advani. As many as 90 crore electors, including 1.59 crore new voters aged 18-19 years, are registered to vote in the upcoming general election. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Unitech gets GMDA notice for misusing gr.description: GURUGRAM: GMDA issued a notice to developer Unitech Group on Tuesday for allegedly allowing the use of groundwater for construction activities in Nirvana Country. As per the notice, the developer has given groundwater connections to buildings that are currently under construction or without an occupation certificate, which is not permissible under the norms. According to GMDA officials, they had received a complaint from a Nirvana resident stating that groundwater is being used for construction activities in the township. “We have asked the developer to cut all such connections and submit a report within seven days from the date of the notice,” a senior GMDA official said. A copy of the notice, accessed by TOI, stated that in the wake of water shortage faced by the residents of Gurugram, the developer is directed to disconnect all such connections in conformation with the National Building Code, 2016 and MCG Act, 1994. “We’ve also directed the developer to ensure that all such under-construction buildings under the purview of the Nirvana RWA use water from sewage treatment plants for construction purposes,” the official added. There are around 50 under-construction houses in Nirvana Country. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

AMMK Candidate List 2019.description: CHENNAI: AMMK deputy general secretary TTV Dhinakaran on Friday released the second and final list of candidates - 14 for the Lok Sabha polls and 9 for assembly bypoll in Tamil Nadu. The party has decided to field two of its heavyweight disqualified MLAs to contest Lok Sabha polls and to take on strong candidates from AIADMK alliance. Disqualified MLA from Andipatti and AMMK propaganda secretary, Thanga Tamilselvan, has been fielded from Theni Lok Sabha constituency, he will take on P Ravindranath Kumar, son of deputy chief minister and AIADMK coordinator O Paneerselvam. Disqualified MLA from Paapireddipatti and former minister P Palaniappan will be contesting the Lok Sabha polls from Dharmapuri constituency. He will take on PMK youth wing leader and former Union health minister Anbumani Ramadoss, who is contesting on behalf of the AIADMK-BJP-PMK alliance.| Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in Tamil NaduBesides these two, AMMK has also selected another disqualified MLA, NG Parthibhan from Sholingar assembly segment, to contest Arakonam Lok Sabha constituency. He will take on former Unions minister of state S Jagathrakshakan of the DMK - Congress alliance on the seat. AMMK had earlier released its first list of 24 candidates for Lok Sabha and 9 candidates for assembly bypoll in the state last Sunday. Dhinakaran will release the party's manifesto for the Lok Sabha polls later during the day. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Murder case filed a month after NIT stud.description: KURUKSHETRA: A month after National Institute of Technology (NIT)-Kurukshetra student Ritik Batra was reported to have died after falling from the third floor of institute’s Hostel No. 10, the police on Monday registered a case of murder. The case was registered on the complaint of Ritik’s father Rajnish Batra, who suspects that his son was murdered. Ritik belonged to Karnal and was a first-year student of B.Tech at the NIT-Kurukshetra. In the FIR, Rajnish Batra said, “Ritik was living in Room No. 123 of Hostel No. 1 of the NIT- Kurukshetra and I talked to him last on May 20, at around 10 pm. After an hour, my wife received a call on her mobile from someone to inform that Ritik had fallen from third floor. We rushed to Kurukshetra but on the way were informed that he was being taken to a private hospital in Karnal and we reached there.” After some time, in an unconscious condition, Ritik was brought to the hospital in Karnal by his roommate Shivam and warden DK, he stated. On May 21, he shifted his son to a private hospital in Gurugram for better treatment, where he succumbed to his injuries on May 29 at around 7 pm. “On May 30, policemen from Third Gate police post in Kurukshetra reached Gurugram, who told us that they had inquired into the matter and found that Ritik died after slipping from the third floor of Hostel No. 10. My son’s mobile, bag, purse, ATM and Aadhaar card are missing. My son lived in Hostel No. 1 but the incident is reported to be from Hostel No. 10. So far, the police have not obtained the call details of my son’s mobile, neither have they obtained the CCTV footage from Hostel No. 10. I suspect that my son has been murdered,” his FIR read. Talking to TOI, Rajnish Batra said, “In the post-mortem report, the doctors disclosed the cause of death due to internal injuries in chest and spine. But, Ritik did not have any external injury which is impossible if someone falls from the third floor. I visited the spot in the hostel where he had fallen, but found no sign of blood or any such mark there. I suspect my son was murdered.” Following this complaint, on June 17, the Kurukshetra University (KU) police station registered a case under Section 302 (murder) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) to start the investigation. KU SHO Balwan Singh said, “We have registered a case on the statement of Ritik’s father and it is being investigated. Earlier in the police inquiry, it was found that he had died after falling from the third floor of the hostel but now his father has raised a suspicion about the cause of his son’s death and the case is being investigated accordingly now.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Chronic congestion: Gurugram has 22 pain.description: GURUGRAM: Traffic police have identified 22 spots in the city as chronic congestion-prone areas, based on traffic records for the months of April and May. In the past two months, 381 instances of traffic congestion have been reported from these areas, revealed the cumulative data compiled by the department. That includes 197 instances of traffic jams from the 22 spots in April, and 184 instances from 15 areas in May. Closer analysis of the data reveals most instances of traffic congestion have been reported from seven spots, namely, Sirhaul toll plaza, Signature Towers, Sheetla Mata mandir road, Ghata mod, Atlas FoB, Daultabad flyover and Tikri cut, which accounted for about 60% of the total number of jams. Of these, Sirhual toll recorded the maximum number of congestions, 47, followed closely by Signature Towers with 43 and 33 at Ghata mod. The data also reveals that duration of these jams range from 1.5 minutes to 5 hours. The longest congestion for the two months was in Sirhaul toll. The spot witnessed a 5-hour-long jam in April, as well as a two-hour-long jam in May. Following Sirhaul in the list, Atlas FoB and Ghata mod recorded long jams of about 50 minutes to an hour each. Commenting on Sirhaul, DCP (traffic) Himanshu Garg told TOI, “Sirhaul is the most challenging area due to a huge bottleneck. About 21 lanes on the Gurugram side converge into 4 lanes on the Delhi side, leading to heavy congestion.” He added that the data reports and subsequent inspections of the area by senior officials, including himself, has helped address a lot of challenges, like fixing of a sharp turn at Dwarka link road. Gurugram’s vulnerability to perennial traffic snarls is one thing that unites all denizens of Millennium City, which is otherwise is a city of contradictions. Be it commuters from neighbouring cities or residents, the congestion affects all. As a result, traffic cops and their efforts are always under scanner. To find a lasting solution, traffic police resorted to gathering and analysing data earlier this year. The department claimed not only does the exercise help them keep a track on major congestion spots, so that they can deploy force to ease traffic flow, but also help them devise policy and carry out enforcement drives. The department records data daily, which is complied as monthly reports that act as a good reference point for the department. “Through these reports, we identify priority areas and devise strategy to manage traffic flow, from spots that need deployment of additional forces or barricades, to cuts in the media that need to be opened or closed, etc. Based on these reports, our officials visit key areas to figure root causes of problems. If it’s a structural issue like faulty roads, we speak to the concerned department to resolve the issue,” said Garg. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Central panel nixes AIIMS plan in Rewari.description: GURUGRAM: A committee appointed by the Union ministry of environment, forest and climate change (MoEF&CC) has turned down a proposal to build an AIIMS in Manethi village of Rewari. The project was planned over 235 acres falling under Aravali plantation. The committee rejected the proposal saying the area has dense forest with 16,000 trees and 21,000 plants, and is home to many wild species including black buck (Haryana’s state animal) and sambhar. Sources in the ministry said the project was turned down because of two factors. “First, Haryana already has very low forest cover — at 3.59% of its geographical area. Second, Manethi has dense forest with over 16,000 fully-grown trees and is home to many wild species,” said an official, requesting anonymity. Even though the district administration proposed to divert land to the forest department in Masani barrage, so that non-forest activity could be carried out in Manethi, the committee turned down the proposal and suggested the state government should look for alternatives. “Destroying existing, dense forest at Manethi and carrying out fresh plantation at Masani barrage will not only be destructive for the environment, but also will not be cost effective. We’ve suggested the government should look for an alternative site. In fact, Masani barrage could be a good option to build the healthcare facility,” said the official. Calling it a violation of the Supreme Court judgement, former forest conservator R P Balwan told TOI, “The proposal was bound to be rejected. In the case of T N Godavarman Thirumulpad vs Union of India, the Supreme Court clearly said ‘forest’ must be understood according to its ‘dictionary meaning’. In many other orders, the same was reiterated by the Apex court. The Aravali plantation, therefore, is clearly deemed forest. Authorities should have applied their mind before proposing a project on forest land. There is a large chunk of land owned by panchayats in the state. Establishing AIIMS is certainly important, but it can easily be planned on panchayat or private land.” Talking about the importance of the Manethi forest, renowned forester and former principal chief conservator of forests (Rajasthan) R N Mehrotra, said, “Manethi has dense forest which is home to many wild species. Most importantly, the globally threatened White-naped Tit (parus nuchalis) is found here. Also, the Aravali foothills have huge ecological importance as it recharges groundwater. There is a need to protect such forests as we are already facing climate emergency.” During 1990s and 2000s, European Union funds were spent to carry out plantation in the Aravalis. Nearly 3.3 crore trees were planted at a cost of Rs 175 crore, over 30,000 hectares across 13 districts that comprise of Aravalis in Haryana. That included district Rewari, where plantation was carried out on 412 hectare in Manethi. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

MCG focuses on waste to better swachh ra.description: GURUGRAM: MCG on Wednesday discussed various parameters that can decide the ranking of a city in the Swachh Survekshan Survey 2020, in order to upgrade Gurugram’s position in the national list. Gurugram was ranked 85 in the 2019 survey, and 105 in 2018. At the meeting, MCG joint commissioners Hariom Atri and Inderjit Kulharia discussed ways by which the sanitation department can overcome hurdles it faces. Apart from making the city open-defecation free, MCG officials also stressed on segregation of garbage and monitoring of waste generators. They also discussed how to process the accumulated garbage at the existing site in Bandhwari. All sanitation officials were advised to spread awareness on waste segregation in all colonies and plotted societies. “The door-to-door garbage collection programme, registering informal waste pickers, ban of single-use plastic, new waste processing facility, remediation of existing dump sites, are some of the prerequisites to gain Swachh Survekshan points, so we’re concentrating on waste collection and processing. Also, this year there’s 10% extra for educating people about cleanliness,” said a senior MCG official. Sanitation officers were directed to map out the city’s perennially filthy areas, where cleanliness drives can be carried out in the next few months. Recently, MCG commissioner Vinay Singh issued a directive to impose fines on residents who failed to segregate wet and dry waste. This year, the survey will be decided by evaluating a city’s performance in the three quarters left — April to June, July to September, October to December. The parameters include capacity building, collection and transportation of solid waste, processing and disposal of waste, sustainable sanitation and information, education and communication regarding waste, all of which carry different maximum points which a city can score by fulfilling the targets. 10 junctions in New Gurugram to get 100.description: GURUGRAM: To monitor the traffic movement and carry out surveillance at major junctions in the city, the Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA) is all set to start work on its much talked about project — Public Safety and Adaptive Traffic Management System — in a few weeks. Divided in three phases, GMDA plans to install 220 CCTV cameras in the first phase. Around 100 cameras will be installed at 10 junctions in New Gurugram and will be connected to the integrated control and command centre (ICCC). According to the officials , the survey of these 10 junctions has been completed and the installation work will be completed by July second week. There will be nine monitoring stations — the ICCC and eight police stations. “The feed from the cameras will be displayed at the ICCC and will be monitored by an internal team. Once we finish installing these 100 cameras, we will start work on the installation of the other 120 cameras,” a GMDA official said. He added that the feed from these cameras will be put into various analytics software such as facial recognition, speed violation detection system, e-challans, automatic number plate recognition system and signal violation detection system and the output will be used by GMDA, Gurugram police and other government agencies. “We will be using different types of camera, including general surveillance, PTZ (pan–tilt–zoom), automatic number plate recognition and traffic signal violation detection cameras. This system will help us identify repeat offenders too,” an official said. In all, 360 CCTV cameras will be installed across the city, in phases, under the smart city project. Meanwhile, the work at the ICCC is almost complete and the command and control centre will be functional by mid-July. TOI had earlier reported that the Gurugram police and the administration will have advanced technology to aid their public safety and traffic management system as the GMDA’s CCTV camera project kicks in. The project will start with the cameras being installed at 220 intersections in its first leg. Another 140 intersections will be covered subsequently. In the pre-implementation phase, GMDA had surveyed the junctions, set the layout and the monitoring facility at the intersections and police stations. A preliminary survey had already been done by the authority where they have made detailed drawings of all the junctions and identified the number and category of cameras required at those junctions. “We have already decided the placement, number and type of cameras with the help of the survey,” an official said. Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil. Mamata Banerjee.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Projecting TDP supremo and AP chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu as a “national leader of importance” and keeping the debate on the alternate front prospects in the ensuing elections alive, West Bengal chief minister and Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee appealed to people of AP to elect TDP again to keep the duo of Narendra Modi and Amit Shah away from power. “Who is Modi to ask about our Prime Minister candidate? We will decide who to elect our leader as there will be alternative for Modi,” she pointed out. Mamata said Naidu has done a lot for development of Andhra Pradesh. “It’s a necessity for AP people to give the power to Naidu again as he will play a key role in national politics and show a path of development to the entire country,” she added. Addressing a public meeting convened by TDP on Sunday, Mamata said Naidu is the leader to take the country forward. “Like he has done in Andhra Pradesh, Naidu can do a lot in Delhi,” she said. Coming down heavily on Modi, Mamata appealed the gathering to save the country and remove Modi (desh ko bachana hai to Modi ko hatao). “Modi claimed to be chaiwala after 2014 elections. Now he says he is chowkidar,” she added. “But chowkidar for whom? For those who looted the country. Modi had claimed that demonitisation would mitigate terrorism and stop black money, but ironically the number of terrorist attacks was the highest in the past two years. Under Modi’s regime, more number of farmers committed suicide and unemployment increased.” She added that Modi failed to explain the Pulawama incident and the Rafale deal and spurned the demand for an all-party meeting on the issues. “The nation does not want leaders like Narendra Modi and Amit Shah,” she asserted, and challenged Modi for an open debate on a national channel of his choice to discuss issues facing the country. All DLF-2 homes to harvest rainwater.description: GURUGRAM: At a time when several parts of the city are facing water shortage and the groundwater table is depleting every year at an alarming rate, residents of DLF-2 have come together to conserve rainwater in their area. Starting Monday, residents will be filling out forms in which they will describe the status of rainwater harvesting sites in DLF-2 and how they can be improved. Every resident will also install rainwater harvesting units at their own house. These forms will be submitted to the Gurugram deputy commissioner. At present, the city has a total of 627 rainwater harvesting pits. There is a dire requirement for more rainwater pits in the city, as per various government agencies. The district administration started a survey to assess the city’s groundwater levels and water reservoirs three months ago, and it is expected to conclude in July. Residents hope their initiative will aid the district administration in the survey. “Increasing groundwater recharge and controlling extraction is the need of the hour. We have around 5,000 residents in DLF-2, and will distribute forms to them to get a clear picture of the scenario in our area,” Gaurav Wahi, general secretary of DLF-2 RWA, said.
