A lot more needs to be done in field of.description: “I have had a very chequered career, if you may say,” confesses Ajoy Khandheria, an engineer by qualification and ‘entrepreneur evangelist’ with 25 years of experience, mostly in the telecom space. He is also the founder of Gramin Healthcare, a startup that, since 2016, has endeavoured to make quality healthcare accessible to the rural population. “Rural India still requires a medical practitioner to be physically present there — digital might be a good backup but healthcare delivery requires brick-and-mortar,” maintains Khandheria.  Switching domains I still hold equity in a few telecom companies, in Singapore, Dubai, India, etc., but I decided to go with a startup in healthcare. The first part of that startup was to provide consulting to Tier-2 hospitals and re-engineer them so they could increase their effectiveness. The idea was a replica of what Genpact does — increase the value and then take a share of the increment. But we realised it was very difficult to collect from the promoter in private hospitals. Then we decided to diversify and build orthopaedic and cardiac practices in hospitals in Tier-2 and Tier-3 cities that did not have this service, which was actually not very scalable. From there we morphed into (providing) a second opinion for surgery patients online. Again, that was not scalable because everyone wanted to speak to the same (famous) doctor who could take only that many calls.  Dilemma & solution Some three year ago, a former colleague had joined IFFCO and told me about some horrible debt-trap stories due to hospital bills that drive a number of farmers/labourers to suicide. So, we decided to open brick-and-mortar clinics. IFFCO at that time was setting up IFFCO Bazar’s showrooms in villages by providing guidance to farmers on fertilisers, seeds and crops. But farmers kept demanding from IFFCO that we want healthcare and education. So it was decided that we set up a clinic with IFFCO Bazar. We started off with a partnership but after a few months, they realised the outcomes were good so they agreed to make us shareholders.  Partners in rural health Now we are by far the largest primary-care provider in rural India but we are probably less than 0.1% of the market, so there is a lot more that needs to be done. I hope other people learn from what we are doing because four-five new players will allow us to address 25% of the population over five years. We are also implementing Ayushman Bharat in Maharashtra and Haryana. Currently, we are spread in seven states but working with the Haryana government has been our best experience — they are very aggressive people, interested in doing good work, and very supportive.  Work/life: Finding the balance I actually do not work like an entrepreneur; I give more importance to family than work. Each year for the last eight years, I have spent 60 days straight with my kids. I learn a lot from my kids and I hope they learn something from me. Besides, I follow every sport on Planet Earth. I play golf and another sport which is not considered a sport by some — poker. I co-own Bangalore Warriors, a poker team in a league in India. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Huda City Centre flasher held in Delhi,.description: NEW DELHI: Delhi Police’s special cell has arrested a 25-year-old man who had allegedly flashed at a woman and masturbated on the escalator of Huda City Centre metro station last week. The investigation began after the woman, a 29-year-old who is originally from Delhi but currently lives in Gurugram where she works as a brand manager, tweeted on June 17 about the horror she went through after she had alighted from the metro at the terminal station. In a conversation with TOI, she had also called for measures to make public places more secure for women. The accused has been identified as Gurugram resident Dinesh who, police said, lives in Sushant Lok 2 (Sector 57). He belongs to the Hamirpur area of Uttar Pradesh. Dinesh was nabbed by the special cell from near Rajokri flyover in South Delhi. The woman had identified him in CCTV footage, which Gurugram police had circulated to apprehend the suspect. The special cell got a tip-off about the suspect roaming around air force station near Rajokri and nabbed him. He was handed over to the Gurugram police later in the day. A senior Gurugram police officer said the woman was asked to join the investigation. “She recorded her statement today before the judicial magistrate,” he said. The woman was not aware of the arrest till evening and said she would release a statement only after receiving official word. Police suspect Dinesh is a repeat offender and has misbehaved before with women as well. He is being interrogated. He had allegedly followed the 29-year-old out last Friday as she took the escalator to the station compound around 9.25pm. Sensing something wrong, the woman said she had turned around to find the man standing behind her and masturbating. “I confronted him and slapped him,” she had told TOI on Monday, adding the man, who seemed to be in his mid-20s, had responded with a volley of abuses. She said she also screamed to draw fellow commuters’ attention but no one reacted. “No one came forward, not even the women standing near me,” she had said. “We do not need free rides. We need safety. We want safety which every government has failed to provide despite multiple promises,” the woman had tweeted. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Uttar Pradesh.description: "You're sitting on my grand mother's grave," Salim Shah told this correspondent. She has been buried, he said, in his living room. A clutch of houses in Chah Pokhar in Achnera block of Agra have turned into graveyards as families are forced to bury their departed in their homes due to lack of a burial ground. As a result, the dead here are a constant part of day-to-day life. TOI found women cooking next to where their children were buried while the elderly rested on cots in a backyard full of graves. In one of the houses, Rinki Begum told TOI that five bodies were buried in her backyard, including that of her 10-month-old son who had died of an untreated fever. Another resident, Guddi, said, "For poor people like us, there is no dignity in death. Due to lack of space in houses, people have to sit and walk over graves. It is so disrespectful." Almost all the houses in the block have graves within the compound Most of the Muslim families here are poor and landless and men scout for work as contract labourers. They said their demand for a graveyard has been ignored for years. The pond in Chah Pokhar village, where a piece of land is allocated for the burial ground on papersThe apathy of the administration can be gauged from the fact that a plot allotted for a graveyard some years ago falls right in the middle of a pond. Repeated complaints have fallen on deaf ears and residents are running out of space. The fresh graves are no more cemented to ensure they occupy less space and stones of different sizes kept over them are the only way to tell them apart. Protests have erupted in the past over the issue. In 2017, after the death of resident Mangal Khan, his family refused to bury his body until land for a graveyard was provided in the village. After assurances by the authorities, they buried Khan near the pond. But the promises came to nothing. Living with the dead: A grave in the backyard"All we are asking for is some land for our ancestors. There is a cremation ground for the Hindus in the periphery of the village, but we are living with our dead," said Munim Khan, a factory worker. Desperate residents even tried reaching out to nearby Sanan village and Achnera town that have burial grounds. But they were not willing to part with precious space. "These two villages have a larger Muslim population than Chah Pokhar. Their burial grounds are filled to capacity," said Nizam Khan, a mechanic. Village pradhan Sundar Kumar said that he had asked officials several times for a burial ground for Muslim families, but no action was taken. Ravi Kumar NG, the district magistrate, said that he was not aware of the issue. "I will send an official team to the village and get details of the burial land required." Picture Credit: Hemant Kumar In Video:Houses turn into graveyards as Muslims in this UP village bury the dead at homeDownload The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Rs 100 fine for not sorting waste: MCG.description: GURUGRAM: From July 1, households which don’t segregate their waste will be fined Rs 100 per day. MCG commissioner Vinay Singh issued the directive to senior officials of the sanitation department in a meeting on Tuesday. MCG had issued an advisory on Saturday stating that it is mandatory for residents to segregate their waste. Every household has been advised to install two separate bins — blue for dry waste and green for wet waste — outside their house for the MCG waste collection vans. Defaulters will be given 10 days’ warning period before they are fined, the commissioner said. Singh also asked officials to begin treating the city’s construction and demolition (C&D) waste at the earliest. The corporation is planning to launch two mobile treatment units that will treat C&D waste at 14 designated sites where such waste is being dumped every day, officials said. Officials were further directed to start the Basai C&D waste processing unit soon. Gurugram currently has no plant to process such waste. Directives were also issued to identify bulk waste generating sites in the city and treat waste after segregation. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Lok Sabha Poll 2019.description: LUCKNOW: With electioneering for the 2019 Lok Sabha polls gaining steam in Uttar Pradesh, political leaders are increasingly resorting to personal attacks on their adversaries. If the maverick BJP MLA from Bairia, Surendra Singh hit the headlines for his remarks against BSP supremo Mayawati, Uttar Pradesh cabinet minister Shrikant Sharma hit a new low by making indecent comments on Congress chief Rahul Gandhi. The Bairia MLA had said Mayawati gets facials done and her hair coloured even though she is 60-years-old. He also reportedly made offensive remarks against UPA chairperson Sonia Gandhi and Haryanvi singer-dancer Sapna Chaudhary, evoking widespread criticism from political parties and social media users. A media agency quoted him as saying that both Sonia Gandhi and Sapna Chaudhary used to work as dancers. "Rahul's mother (Sonia Gandhi) was also in the same profession in Italy and his father made her his own. He (Rahul Gandhi) should also take the family tradition forward and make Sapna his own," the MLA said. The BJP legislator, who is known for his controversial statements, had earlier termed Rahul Gandhi and his sister Priyanka Gandhi Vadra "Ravana and Shurpanakha", and accused Mayawati of "murdering" a woman's dignity by joining hands with one-time arch rival Samajwadi Party. UP Power Minister Shrikant Sharma stirred up a hornet's nest with his tweet terming the Congress president a "coward and impotent". The comments triggered a war of words between the two parties as well as on social media platform. Firebrand Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath also finds mention in the list of leaders accused of making personal remarks against political rivals. He recently termed Congress candidate from Saharanpur, Imran Masood, the son-in-law of Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Azhar Masood. Addressing a rally in Saharanpur on Sunday, Adityanath said, "The son-in-law of Azhar Masood has entered the constituency and he speaks the language of the terror mastermind. "You people have to ensure that the person who speaks the language of Azhar Masood is defeated in the Lok Sabha elections," he said while seeking votes for BJP candidate from Saharanpur, Raghav Lakhanpal. Union minister and BJP MP Mahesh Sharma referred to Rahul Gandhi as 'Pappu' and his sister Priyanka Gandhi as 'Pappu ki Pappi' during a poll campaign in Gautam Buddh Nagar. Rahul Gandhi has often been mocked by the BJP and his opposition as 'Pappu', a colloquial sneer. "Pappu kehta hai main prime minister banunga Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu.. aur ab 'Pappu ki Pappi' bhi aa gayi hai. Wo Priyanka kya pehle hamare desh ki beti nahi thi kya, Congress ki beti nahi thi kya, aage nahi rahegi kya? kya naya leke aayi hai?" the minister told a crowd of his supporters on March 16. The quotes loosely translate to "Pappu says he wants to become prime minister. Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu ... and now 'Pappu's Pappi' has also arrived. Wasn't Priyanka already a daughter of this nation, a daughter of the Congress? And would she not remain so in future? What new has she brought in?" BJP List 2019 WB.description: KOLKATA: The BJP in its first list of 28 candidates for West Bengal has pinned hopes on its veterans and defectors from the ruling Trinamool Congress to take on the Mamata Banerjee's government in the state. Of the 28 candidates, nearly 25 are new faces, with a thrust on active political workers rather than greenhorns from the glamour world. The saffron party, which bagged two Lok Sabha seats in the 2014 elections, is now targeting 23 of the state's 42 constituencies. BJP Lok Sabha first full listUnlike the TMC list, which had 18 new faces and a mix of both old-timers and greenhorns, hardcore politicians and personalities from the film industry, the BJP has put faith on its own leaders and defectors from other parties. There are four women candidates and one Muslim nominee in the first list. Of the candidates, five had recently defected to the saffron party from the Trinamool Congress and one from the CPI(M). West Bengal: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageUnion minister and BJP MP from Asansol Lok Sabha constituency Babul Supriyo has been renominated from the same seat and is pitted against actor Moon Moon Sen of the TMC. State BJP president Dilip Ghosh will contest from Medinipur seat against TMC leader Manas Bhunia. BJP national secretary Rahul Sinha will take on TMC heavyweight Sudip Bandopadhyay in Kolkata North Lok Sabha seat. State BJP vice-president and Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose grandnephew, Chandra Kumar Bose will contest from Kolkata South Lok Sabha seat. Former IPS officer Bharati Ghosh, once known to be close to Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, will be fighting against TMC candidate and actor Dipak Adhikary, popularly known as 'Dev', from Ghatal Lok Sabha constituency. The BJP has fielded former Trinamool Congress MLA Arjun Singh from Barrackpur Lok Sabha seat. Singh, who had recently joined the saffron party, has been pitted against TMCs Dinesh Trivedi. In Coochbebar Lok Sabha seat, the party has fielded former TMC youth leader Nishith Pramanik, while in Jadavpur Lok Sabha seat, expelled TMC MP Anupam Hazra will contest against TMC's Mimi Chakraborty, an actor by profession. Another former TMC MP Soumitra Khan, who joined the BJP in January, has been given ticket from Bishnupur(SC) Lok Sabha seat. Former CPI(M) MLA Khagen Murmu, who too had switched over to the BJP, will contest from Malda North seat and will take on TMCs Mausam Benazir Noor, who had recently defected to the party from the Congress, in Malda Uttar seat. The Lok Sabha elections in the state will be held from April 11 till May 19 in seven phases. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

AIIMS can't be built on forest land, Rao.description: GURUGRAM: Congress leader and former minister Captain Ajay Yadav has demanded Gurugram MP Rao Inderjit Singh’s resignation, alleging that he cheated the people of Rewari by promising AIIMS in Manethi village of the district. Yadav, who was the forest minister during the Congress regime, said he had been saying AIIMS can’t be set up on the land in Manethi village as it falls in the forest area, and now the forest advisory committee (FAC) of ministry of environment, forest and climate change (MoEF & CC) has denied environmental clearance to the project. However, when contacted, Inderjit Singh said the matter is under consideration with the Centre. “We are working on it. The issue of land for AIIMS in Rewari will be sorted out soon,” he said. During the Lok Sabha election campaign, Inderjit had promised to set up AIIMS in Rewari. A source in the chief minister’s office said Manohar Lal Khattar had in 2015 announced setting up of AIIMS in Manethi village of Rewari. However, when nothing happened till 2018, villagers went on an indefinite strike which lasted for 127 days. Before the Lok Sabha elections, the BJP government in the state had cleared the project worth Rs 1,299 crore in a cabinet meeting. It also earmarked 200-acre land with the help of the panchayat. Speaking to TOI, Yadav said the BJP MP should resign on moral grounds as he has played with the sentiments of people of south Haryana. “Even the former finance minister of the country had announced that funds have been passed for AIIMS. But it turned out to be another ‘jumla’ before the elections,” he said. He further said even Prime Minister Narendra Modi was aware that AIIMS could not be built in Manethi and “therefore he did not lay the foundation stone for the project”.He further said the BJP will face a setback in the forthcoming assembly elections The people have realised that the saffron party made false promises to them while seeking votes, he added. Rao Inderjit Singh is a former Congressman. He joined BJP later and won Lok Sabha elections in 2014 from Gurugram constituency. He contested against Congress’s Ajay Yadav in the 2019 Lok Sabha polls and defeated him by a huge margin of around 4 lakh votes. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Gurugram: MG Road stays bumpy, littered.description: GURUGRAM: Damaged dividers, footpaths either broken or encroached upon, carriageways riddled with patchwork and potholes and illegal parking on the roadside. This sums up a visitor’s experience of the city’s arterial link — MG Road. With numerous malls, residential apartments, public and private offices along it, the road is forever jam-packed with commuters, especially during peak hours. The volume of traffic can be gauged from the presence of two of the city’s main metro stations here — MG Road and Sikanderpur — used daily by lakhs of officegoers from the city and its NCR neighbours. The administration has made many commitments in the past towards maintaining and beautifying the stretch. Last year, many master roads in the city, including MG Road, were transferred to GMDA. In December 2018, the department had announced that it would conduct repair and maintenance work on 12 stretches by March. However, TOI’s visit revealed that six months later, MG Road is still in a bad shape. Apart from the poor condition of the surface, chronic traffic jams during peak office hours, often due to wrong-side driving that broken dividers and illegal parking seem to encourage, make commute a harrowing experience on this road. Commenting on the GMDA’s efforts to address the challenges posed by this stretch, an official revealed the department is rolling out a Rs 11-crore project to upgrade it. “The tender has been allotted to a private firm that will repair this stretch — from Mehrauli-Gurugram Road to IFFCO Chowk, via Sikanderpur road — by layering bitumen all over. The contractor will also be liable for its maintenance for three years from the time work is completed,” the official said. He further pointed out that while earlier repair work on this stretch came under the department’s annual maintenance, the current project is listed as a special repair work. The 15m-green belt on either side is also in a deplorable state, with garbage, including C&D waste, littered on it and spilling over on the road. Commuters fear if the administration doesn’t take prompt action, this could spell doom in the monsoons. “I don’t know why we even call this a green belt. Fences lie broken, garbage is littered on it with no one to clean that. It’s as if the administration will wake up only during monsoon when garbage floods the road and chokes the drains,” said Nirmit, a commuter from Delhi. Urmila Matondkar.description: MUMBAI: The Congress on Friday nominated actress Urmila Matondkar and former Lok Sabha speaker Meira Kumar from Mumbai North and Bihar's Sasaram parliamentary constituencies respectively. The party renominated its sitting MP Ranjet Ranjan from Supaul in Bihar, as it released a list of another 12 candidates for the general elections. With this list, the Congress has so far nominated 305 Lok Sabha candidates. Urmila Matondkar to contest from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency on a Congress ticket.… https://t.co/JweKWNh1FN— ANI (@ANI) 1553836382000It also changed its candidate in Uttar Pradesh's Maharajganj by now fielding Supriya Shrinate in place of Tanushree Tripathi, the daughter of jailed politician Amarmani Tripathi, after facing widespread criticism. "The Congress central election committee has approved the candidature of Urmila Matondkar as party candidate to contest the ensuing general elections from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency in Maharashtra," a party statement said. Matondkar had joined the Congress after meeting Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday and had later said that she was "here to stay". Meira Kumar have been contesting from her Sasaram parliamentary constituency for many years but had lost in the 2014 Lok Sabha polls. Apart from Supriya Shrinate, in the list of 12 candidates released by the party, four are from Bihar and seven from Odisha. The Congress also released a list of 20 candidates for Odisha Assembly election. Clad in a sleeveless hand-embroidered high-quality multi-functional jacket, the actor was seen sharing nitty-gritties of acting and his idea about fashion and style. Two weeks left, 1,518 apply for Gurugram.description: By: Ipsita Pati GURUGRAM: Gurugram University (GU) is preparing to welcome 720 students this academic session With just two more weeks left before completion of the admission session at the university on July 2, a total of 1,518 applicants have applied for 22 courses so far. The university is also introducing 11 new courses this session. With the new addition, its total strength will be 1,240 students. Last year, GU had received a total of around 1,600 applications. University officials are hoping that they will get more applicants this academic session, the admissions to which will be closed on July 2. “We’ve so far received 1,518 applications for 720 seats. We’ve increased the number of seats and courses this year. The entire application process is also online. For humanities stream, students are advised to apply through Kurukshetra University and for science stream, students should apply through Maharshi Dayanand University,” a university spokesperson said. As GU has a centralised procedure for admission, students have to go through an entrance test. “Students are admitted to the university on the basis on merit,” a senior professor from the law faculty said. New courses introduced this year include MA (journalism and mass communication), MPharma, Master of physiotherapy, Master of social science, MSc (neuroscience), MSc (actuarial science), MA (administration) and MA (economics), LLM, post-graduate (PG) diploma in corporate law and PG diploma in labour law. In April 2017, the Haryana cabinet had approved a Bill to set up a state university in Gurugram, which has been a long-standing demand of students of the area, who have to travel either to Delhi or other cities for higher education. The university’s own campus is not yet completed. It operates out of the campus of Rao Tularam College of Science and Commerce in Sector 51. With GU’s own campus in Sector 85 still under construction, it is expected to take another two years, and around Rs 700 crore, for it to become fully functional. Three more cases of narcotics recovery r.description: AMBALA: In three separate cases, Ambala police on Tuesday recovered 24gm heroin (smack), 1000 narcotic pills and 31kg poppy straw from the possessions of five accused. The accused have been booked in three more separate cases under various Sections of the Narcotics Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act. In the first case, at around 8.40pm, the police team of Barara was present at checking post near Ugala village when they stopped a suspected Pulsar motorcycle for checking. The police said while checking, 40 capsules of Spasmo Proxyvon with Tramadol salt, 840 tablets of Lomotil, and 120 tablets of Alprasafe were recovered from the possession of accused Surjit Singh of Ugala village in Ambala district. He has been booked under Section 22 and 61 of the NDPS Act at Barara police station. In the second case, police told they received the tip-off that Nishu Sonkar of Teli Mandi, Ambala Cantonment sells narcotic substances and he will be coming near Puran Singh Hotel. At 10.20 pm, acting accordingly the police laid the trap near the vegetable market in Ambala Cantonment, where 24gm heroin (smack) was recovered from Nishu’s possession. He has been booked under Section 21 (punishment for contravention in relation to manufactured drugs and preparations) of the NDPS Act at Parao police station. In the third case, crime investigation agency (CIA)-2 received the tip-off that three Ludhiana residents are coming in their car from Madhya Pradesh who are smuggling poppy straw in large quantity on Grand Trunk (GT) Road. Acting accordingly, a checking post was laid near Devinagar toll plaza where the suspected car was stopped. While checking, the police recovered 31kg poppy straw from the possession of three accused identified as Balbir Singh, Gulshan Kumar, and Sunny all residents of villages in Ludhiana district. All three have been booked under Section 15 of the NDPS Act at Ambala Sadar police station. The police officials told, “On Wednesday all the arrested accused have been presented before the court by separate teams. The accused Surjit Singh has been taken on four-day police remand with Barara police, Nishu on two-day police remand with Parao police, and accused Balbir Singh on seven-day police remand while his accomplices Gulshan and Sunny are sent to judicial custody.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

20 DLF-4 homes on government\u2019s rada.description: GURUGRAM: As many as 20 homes constructed in an upscale area of the city are under the scanner of the city authorities for illegal construction. Developer DLF has written to the department of town and country planning (DTCP), deputy commissioner and MCG, alleging that several plot owners in DLF-4 had carried out illegal constructions. The developer also claimed plot owners are constructing buildings with more than five floors, violating the rules. As per the norms, owners cannot construct buildings with more than four floors on an individual plot. Till now, DLF has submitted a list of around 850 such plots in different phases of DLF and the DTCP had sealed nearly three dozen houses on Golf Course Road recently. The plot owners, it has been alleged, build additional floors after getting occupation certificates from DTCP. In some cases, the buildings constructed for residential purposes are used for commercial activities in violation of the rules. “We would like to bring to your notice that some plot owners are illegally constructing their houses beyond sanctioned plan,” said DLF in its letter to the authorities. “Such illegal constructions put additional burden on the existing infrastructure like sewerage, drainage, road and power supply of the colonies causing inconvenience to other residents,” said a resident of DLF-4, adding that in some of these cases people have turned homes into commercial units, causing nuisance in the area. In most cases, these buildings are used for setting up guesthouses and in some other cases, they have leased out buildings to app-based accommodation facilities. Senior town planner (STP) Sudhir Chouhan said DTCP is issuing notices regularly and sealing drives have been conducted, but plot owners go to court and manage to get stay. “It obstructs our drive. Still the department is pursuing it. Courts are ordering stay even without giving us chance to put forth our views,” said Chouhan. He also said the DTCP is empowered to take action under Urban Area Act 1975 in the municipal limit. However, courts grant stay in contravention of the Act’s Section 3B. Chouhan said he had been in the court personally to take up the issue. The department, he said, is now planning to approach the apex court on this matter. As per the Section 3B of Haryana Development And Regulation of Urban Areas Act, 1975, no person is allowed to carry out constructions violating the approved plan. If they carry out construction in violation of approved plan, they will face action from the department. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

From online to the library: When kids sw.description: On a hot June afternoon, sisters Pooja, 14, and Kajal, 13, make their way through the narrow lanes of Sikanderpur village, rushing past water tankers and bikes, to volunteer at the Community Library Project, in a Gurugram beyond the malls and highrises. Every day, these teen siblings, pupils of the government senior secondary school in Chakkarpur, confidently wear the badge of student counsellors, while also helping in member outreach through community walks. The library – free, open to all, and stocking a wide variety of books – presents a safe learning space for those who do not have access to literature. It has 1,100 members, of which 600 are active. Shubha, a staff member here, calls this their library movement. “Once other citizens realise the importance of libraries, there will be more of them, and we are demonstrating it through our models,” she tells TOI. So, there’s Manisha, 11, who, recalls Shubha, would initially flip through books and admire illustrations. A year later, she has finished the Hindi translations of six of the Harry Potter series. And Kajal, who trains in a parlour before visiting the library. She wants to become a librarian when she grows up. Mohsin, 16, is another promising child, who yearns to be a cop when he’s old enough – and, also, be useful around the library on his free Sundays. “I used to while away my summer holidays but now I feel I am learning more geography and history,” shares an eager Mohsin, whose mother works as a domestic help. Tech doesn’t have the touchAt a time when millennials and kids are plugged into their smartphones and tablets, the space for libraries, both intellectually and physically, is shrinking. But seeing the success of Treasure Trove, you wouldn’t think so. Recently, this quaint library, tucked into a basement of a daycare centre to the south of Gurugram, completed nine years. Quirky quotes and colourful posters welcome you to a paradise for the young bibliophile, which has hosted storytelling sessions with popular children’s writer Jeeva Raghunath (who pioneered the storytelling movement in Tamil Nadu) and South African storyteller Bongiswa Kotta Ramushwana. “When we moved from Bangalore to Gurugram 10 years back, there was no children’s library here. My daughter loved reading books and my son loved solving jigsaw puzzles. I would buy books but they would finish it in a day or two – that is when I conceived the idea of a library,” says founder Arvinda Bhatia. “You can order books online but there are so many new authors who are not read because they are not suggested online – that is where we come into the picture, (by) suggesting you explore a new book,” she adds. Bhatia remembers a seven-year-old Akshat Gupta, who would cram even the smallest details and conversations while reading at Treasure Trove. He would go on to write seven books in a span of three years. Akshat’s works are given pride of place at the library where he started reading. You can bond with a bookAcross the road is another school library, also accessible to everyone, which houses an eclectic collection for kids between the ages of two and 12 (from ‘Why Mosquitoes Buzz in People’s Ears’ by Oliver Jeffers to Julia Donaldson’s ‘The Gruffalo’). The stock at Bookhive, running since 2014, consists of titles the husband-wife duo of Ajay and Ashima Chawla would handpick from their travels. Both developed a love of reading and storytelling because of their son (now in college). “Kindle, iPad or any digital media cannot replace the actual touch and feel of a book,” Ashima insists. “It’s not just having a collection of books but having the right kind of books – Oliver Jeffers’ ‘The Day the Crayons Quit’ happens to be the favourite among children of 3-4 years of age,” she reveals, mentioning, proudly, that her most devoted readers are the class-I and class-II children who have finished more than 200 books. The pair recommends other reads by figuring out the interests of their young members. “The level of customisation is missing when one browses books online from sponsored suggestions – for instance, how many of us knew the ‘Queen of Pop’ Madonna is also a children’s book writer?” asks Ajay, pertinently. Yet, even online libraries like Bookpal and Iloveread have their patrons, because of the convenience they offer. “Since everything is far off in the city, and there’s a lack of good bookstores, parents prefer home delivery of books to introduce their children to the joy of reading,” says Shefali Malhotra of Iloveread, adding, “We are happy to send extra books for parents too.” These volunteers, then, are ensuring that at a time when webpages dominate, the charm of the printed word doesn’t fade among Generation Next. And it is libraries that are pushing back against the tech tide. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Visiting Saral Kendra? Take the kids too.description: GURUGRAM: If you are visiting the Saral Kendra or any other department at Mini Secretariat in Gurugram and are worried about leaving your child at home, you can now rest easy. A daycare centre that can accommodate about 25 children has been set up for the employees and visitors by the district administration. The centre, which will be thrown open on Wednesday noon, will have a woman attendant to look after children up to seven years of age. There will be an area for feeding babies, a toy section and a corner for changing diapers. Books for children will also be available. “Considering the multiplicity of departments and the inflow of people, we hope to see between 10 and 25 children daily to avail the facility. We will improve the facility based on the feedback we receive. It was a cumulative demand raised by various workers’ union and this has been successfully done by Power Grid in our complex. Three such facilities have been set up,” said deputy commissioner Amit Khatri. He has directed the officials to put up signages in the corners for visitors and employees. “Kindergarten is a basic facility for workers who have kids. It is to facilitate employees who don’t have anybody at home to look after their children. This would help them focus more on their work since they won’t be worried. As soon as we receive the feedback, we will include more things,” added Khatri. There has been a long-pending demand for a daycare centre at the district and sessions court in Gurugram. The new court complex in Sohna, which was inaugurated in December last year, also has a daycare centre for the children of lawyers, judges and litigants. Tamil Nadu Elections.description: Voting for Lok Sabha elections 2019 in Tamil Nadu will take place in a single phase on April 18 as per the notification issued by the Election Commission of India. The counting of votes will take place on May 23. | Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesThe four-cornered contest for the 39 Lok Sabha seats features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). Out of the 39 seats in the state, seven Lok Sabha seats are reserved for SC. The constituencies reserved for SC candidates are Thiruvallur, Kancheepuram, Villupuram, Nilgiris, Chidambaram, Nagapattinam and Tenkasi in Tamil Nadu. | Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesIn the last Lok Sabha polls, AIADMK had a vote share of 44.3 per cent by winning 37 seats. BJP had a vote share of 5.5 per cent by winning just 1 seat, while NDA managed to win two seats with a vote share of 18.5 per cent PMK won one seat and had a vote share of 4.4 per cent. BJP (NDA) had an alliance with PMK. DMK was not able to win on any seat in the last Lok Sabha polls. In Lok Sabha elections 2019, DMK is contesting on 20 seats, while the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Gurugram: Man \u2018specialised\u2019 in.description: GURUGRAM: A notorious criminal, Irshad, member of the Shahid alias Advani gang and wanted in 33 cases, was arrested by the crime branch on Monday night. Cops said the accused is an expert at uprooting ATMs using a pick-up van, taking it to an isolated place and cutting them open with a gas cutter to retrieve the cash. With his arrest, six members — Advani, Amjad, Amitabh, Zullu, Istak and now Irshad — of the seven-man gang have now been put behind bars, and cops said they expect ATM theft cases in the city to come down. Of the 33 cases of ATM theft, loot and snatching against Irshad, 29 are registered at different police stations in Gurugram. Police had announced a Rs 50,000 reward for his arrest. According to police, Shahid Polo is the only gang member at large, that he is on the run and that they are hoping to arrest him soon. The gang has executed a series of ATM thefts in Gurugram and adjoining areas between 2012 and 2018. All members are from Kharkhari village in Mewat, and they have a record of attacking police on several occasions, whenever cops tried to arrest them from their homes. Irshad was arrested by police in connection with an ATM theft in Wazirabad. The case was registered at Sector 53 police station on May 7, and handed over to crime unit of Sector 31. Acting on information, police arrested Irshad from Sohna on Monday. He was produced before court on Tuesday and sent to five-day police custody. “He has been in jail thrice before, and was declared a “proclaimed offender” by court in three cases,” said ACP (crime) Shamsher Singh, adding they are hoping to extract more information during Irshad’s interrogation. The gang specialises in ATM thefts, targeting unmanned ATMs in Gurugram. Police said they used to come to Gurugram in a stolen pick-up van after dark. On reaching their pre-decided target, they would tie the ATM machine with a belt fixed to the pickup van and uproot the machine. They would then load it on the van and drive to an isolated spot, where they would cut open the machine with gas cutter, steal the cash and dump the machine in a lake or pond. Hooda will leave Cong: BJP min.description: KAITHAL: Haryana minister of state for social justice and empowerment Krishan Kumar Bedi on Monday claimed that state politics would see a major twist in the next 10 days as former chief minister Bhupinder Singh Hooda would leave Congress and join another political party. Addressing mediapersons in Kaithal after a meeting with sanity workers, Bedi said Hooda had been feeling sidelined as Congress had ignored his demand of Ashok Tanwar’s removal from the post of party state president. “Hooda is a self-esteemed man and would not stay in the party if his demand is not met,” he claimed. Terming himself as fortune teller, he said that he had predicted split of Indian National Lok Dal (INLD) three-and-a-half years ago. Making another forecast, he said Digvijay Chautala also would leave his brother Dushyant Chautala after the assembly election. Bedi said the BJP government has provided jobs and put in place a fair and transparent system for the purpose. “We are not arrogant, but people support our policy for the state. We are sure public would vote us to power again on the basis of jobs, health, education, and development in the state,” he maintained. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Gurugram: Woman executive stalked, haras.description: GURUGRAM: It’s Friday night. A young woman arrives at Huda City Centre metro station in a Yellow Line train from Delhi and begins walking down, towards the exit. She reaches the escalator that takes people to the station compound. A secure place, seemingly, with CCTV surveillance, and enough people around to make anyone feel safe. But while she is on the escalator, she gets the feeling of being followed. Then she feels a presence just behind her. It gives her the creeps. On Monday afternoon, after a weekend spent poring through CCTV footage, seething at the police’s lack of initiative, and grappling with the question whether to continue staying on in Gurugram or not, the 29-year-old woman decided she would let the world know what had happened at the metro station. On the escalator on Friday night, she had instinctively turned around. It was around 9.25pm.  There were others too, but right in front of her, stood a man, a stranger. He was masturbating. And he was looking at her.“I confronted him and slapped him,” she told TOI on Monday, adding the man, who seemed to be in his mid-20s, responded with a volley of abuses. She said she also screamed to draw fellow commuters’ attention but no one reacted. “No one came forward, not even the women standing near me,” she said, emphasising the need for discussions and measures to increase safety in public spaces, particularly for women. “We do not need free rides. We need safety. We want safety, which every government has failed to provide despite multiple promises,” she wrote in her tweet. “I sent the same message to DMRC and I immediately got a call from them, following which I was asked to identify the man on CCTV footage (which she did). “Gurugram police got in touch with me only after my tweets,” she said. “I want to file a complaint and pursue this case because it is time we start speaking about the need for safe spaces for women,” she added. “But at the same time, I am scared about my own safety.” Police’s delayed response has only made those apprehensions worse. A Gurugram police spokesperson said they would start an investigation. “We received a complaint through Twitter. We have asked her to submit a written application and record her statement on Monday, following which we will start the investigation,” said police spokesperson Subhash Boken. This is the second episode of perverted behaviour to be reported in the last 10 days from a metro train or station compound. Last week, an auto driver was arrested for flashing a woman inside a train between Sikanderpur and MG Road metro stations. When the woman raised an alarm, commuters nabbed him and handed him over to the police. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

575 doctors in Gurugram join strike, mos.description: GURUGRAM: Around 250 elective procedures were put on hold across Gurugram’s many healthcare facilities — both in private hospitals, clinics and the state-run Civil Hospital — after 575 doctors in the city (data shared by IMA-Gurugram) joined the Indian Medical Association (IMA) -organised protest on Monday. OPDs in private and state hospitals also remained shut. Curie Rani, whose elderly father was operated upon last week for hernia at Medanta, and had come from Greater Noida for a follow-up consultation, was stopped from going to the OPD, as it was shut. “I’ve been asked to contact the hospital’s helpline number. My father can hardly walk and I can’t make him travel repeatedly after a surgery. I just hope the hospital staff helps me out,” she said. Sources said Medanta had informed all patients whose appointments were scheduled for Monday that OPDs will remain shut as the doctors would join the IMA protest. Sources said while IMA members did not attend OPDs in Medanta, they provided all other essential services, including surgeries, procedures and investigations. The hospital had advised patients to attend OPDs on Tuesday or Wednesday. The OPD at Civil Hospital was also shut as the doctors joined the protest. “We were informed that Civil Hospital doctors had suspended their OPDs, which usually does not happen, since being a government set-up. But we were overwhelmed by the response. Around 575 doctors in Gurugram suspended non-essential services as well as around 250 elective procedures in hospitals and clinics across Gurugram,” said Dr Ajay Gupta, secretary, IMA-Gurugram. “I cancelled my professional commitments as I had to see a doctor. But when I arrived, I got to know the OPD is closed. Now I’ll have to plan another visit again,” said a disappointed Kapil Gugnani. A majority of doctors at private hospitals, including Fortis, Artemis and Medanata, had joined the IMA protest. At some hospitals, OPDs were completely shut, but some patients were allowed to consult doctors. “Sometimes, results don’t go as expected. Violence is not the way to sort out things. Sometimes it becomes difficult to handle patients and their relatives at the same time. Doctors should have adequate protection, and patients should behave in a civilised manner to understand what the condition of the patient actually was when he/she was brought to the hospital,” said Dr Himanshu Tyagi of Artemis. The protest will conclude at 6am on Tuesday. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Crimes by juveniles up 42% in 5 years, p.description: GURUGRAM: The number of crimes committed by juvenile has risen by 42% in the last five years, reveals the response to an RTI query. From 147 juveniles who faced trial for criminal activities in 2013, the number has shot up to 209 in 2018. In 2019 (till March), 46 juveniles have been booked and apprehended for their involvement in crimes. A police officer said juveniles mostly start with petty crimes like theft and snatching. With time, they graduate to heinous offences like rape and murder. Criminal gangs nurture juveniles and use them to execute crimes as they face lenient punishments under the Juvenile Justice Act, with a maximum punishment of three years in a correction home. According to the data received via an RTI query filed by activist Aseem Takyar, from 147 cases against juveniles in 2013, the number rose to 175 in 2014, and remained almost the same in 2015. Over the next two years, the numbers even dipped to 159 in 2016 and 148 in 2017. But in 2018, it again saw a steep rise. A police officer said most of the big criminals have committed crimes at a young age. To support his argument, he said in January this year, Gurugram police had arrested gangster Kaushal’s aide Chand (21), a shooter who had committed eight murders in Gurugram, Rewari and Delhi, with his first murder recorded in 2013 at the age of 16. At the age of 19, he had played a key role in the murder of rival gangster Mahesh ‘Attack’ in Gurugram 2016. Police said in the ‘Attack’ murder, Chand was accompanied by Sanjeet Vidroh, who was killed in an encounter by Delhi Police in Chhattarpur in 2018. Vidroh was also 16-years-old in 2016 when he took part in Attack’s murder. At 17, he was involved in the murder of liquor baron Manish Gujjar, brother of gangster Binder Gujjar and rival of gangster Sandeep Gadoli, who had by then been killed by Gurugram police in a hotel in Mumbai’s Andheri on July 6, 2016. “These are some incidents in which juveniles committed heinous crimes and went on to become big criminals,” said the police officer, adding that gangs catch them young and train them to become contract killers. In most cases, they start with petty crimes like snatching and theft, and graduate to heinous crimes. Elaborating further, he said teenagers are generally more aggressive and easily manipulated, and don’t come under police radar. In case they are caught, the punishment is lenient. Even for heinous offences like rape or murder, the maximum sentence a juvenile gets is three years in a correction home. ACP (crime) Shamsher Singh on Monday said they had arrested two teenagers in connection with the murder of a trader in Sadar Bazar. “During interrogation, they revealed they were inspired by older gangsters and wanted to emulate them. They picked up the gun to make their mark,” said Singh. A professor of sociology at Delhi School of Economics, Sunil Babu, said besides the juvenile, parents, friends and teachers are all responsible in some way or another for such developments. “Studies have shown that incidents of juvenile crime have increased due to lower social, economic or psychological backgrounds. In cases where juveniles from even well-to-do families venture into crime, their families are the prime reason,” said Babu, adding that it’s important to keep talking to teenagers and monitor their friends and associates. Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. PGIMS doctor's suicide: Strike called of.description: ROHTAK: The strike by resident doctors of PGIMS here over the suicide by an MD student ended on its fourth day on Monday. Dr Omkar of MD final year had committed suicide on Thursday, after which his colleagues had registered an FIR against their head of department Dr Geeta Gathwala, alleging that she had mentally tortured the deceased. Chief adviser of Resident Doctors’ Association, Rohtak, Dr Satbir Singh said that they had a long meeting with PGIMS vice-chancellor Dr O P Kalra and decided to end the strike in the larger interest of patients. “We were assured that maximum compensation would be given to the deceased’s family, the matter would be taken to the chief minister’s office and the police would make no delay in the arrest of accused Dr Geeta Gathwala after proper investigations,” he added. The PGIMS authorities had been trying to persuade the striking doctors, who were so far unwilling to give up their core demands of arrest of Dr Gathwala and Rs 1-crore compensation to the bereaved family. However, the situation changed with new details emerging in the incident and a cross-case being filed against some junior doctors for vandalizing Dr Gathwala’s house. Mall in trouble as town planner finds vi.description: GURUGRAM: The newly-operational Ardee City Mall and multiplex, spread over 5.1 acres in Sector 52, is under the scanner of the department of town and country planning (DTCP) for violation of its approved building plan and unauthorised construction. The senior town planner (STP) of Gurugram has recommended the cancellation of the occupation certificate (OC) of the mall to the director of DTCP following a complaint filed at the CM’s Window. If this happens, this will be first time the OC of such a big and operational commercial building is cancelled in Gurugram. The developer did not respond to calls and messages from this correspondent. In April 2017, Delhi resident Reena Joon had filed a complaint highlighting illegal construction in the mall. In her complaint, Joon said she had bought a shop on the ground floor of the mall. “My shop was on upper ground floor, but the developer (Ardee) made changes in the building after getting OC and now my shop is on the first floor,” she alleged. Taking cognisance of the complaint, the DTCP director had directed the Gurugram STP to submit a report after investigating the allegations. STP Sudhir Chouhan, DTP (planning) RS Batth and DTP (enforcement) Ved Prakash Shehrawat inspected the mall and submitted their report last week. It highlighted that several violations of building plan were found at the mall and recommended that the OC be cancelled till the developer restores the mall as per the approved building plan. Till the unauthorised construction was removed, the report recommended sealing the mall. “During the inspection, we found several violations. We’ve sent our report to the DTCP director with the recommended for cancellation of OC of the mall and multiplex. The no-objection certificate (NOC) of multiplex has been revoked. The director will take the final call on the issue,” Chouhan said. During the inspection, it was found that no approval had been granted for the construction of a multiplex on the third floor of the mall in the original building plan. According to the report, Ardee has violated the approved building plan and made illegal and unauthorised construction — a store room in the lower basement and a fan room and store room in the upper basement. Moreover, changes had been made in the plan on the lower ground, upper ground, ground, first and second floors. The report further mentioned that the developer is still making additional construction and is a continuous offender by neither abiding by the rules of the department nor maintaining the sanctity of the approved building plan. The mall’s building plan was approved in 2012, and it became functional a few months ago. In Video:Gurugram: Ardee Mall in trouble as town planner finds violationsDownload The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Satta King 2019.description: NEW DELHI: Satta Matka is a form of gambling or lottery that had originated before the Independence of India.Originally, the game of Matka gambling involved betting on the opening and closing rates of cotton as transmitted to the Bombay Cotton Exchange from the New York Cotton Exchange, via teleprinters.The modern-day Matka gambling/ Satta King is based on random number selection and betting. The players participating in the Satta Matka game/ gambling are required to choose the right number for winning the game. The player who wins the game becomes Satta King and is rewarded financially. Two of the most famous Matka games are - Kalyan and Worli. The Kalyan Matka gambling was started by Kalyanji Bhagat, a farmer from Gujarat, in 1962 and it ran for all days of the week. Another Matka gambling, New Worli Matka, was started by the Rattan Khatri in 1964 with slight modifications to the rules of the game. Khatri’s Matka ran only five days a week, from Monday to Friday.The modern Matka business is centred around Maharashtra.Some of the terms used in the game and their meaning is given below:    Term Meaning   Matka Matka means earthen pot that were used to draw numbers   Single Any digit between 0 and 9   Jodi/Pair Any pair of two digits between 00 and 99    Patti/Panna Three digit number    Open result / close result Outcome of matka betting   Berij Berij is last digit of jodi's/pair's sum The Google 2018 trends data shows that 'satta' and 'matka' were the top searched words in the Madhya Pradesh state in the year 2018. As per the Google data, 'satta' was the 4th most searched word with a score of 36 and 'matka' came 6th with a score of 23.Any form of Satta Matka gambling is illegal in India.Disclaimer: This content is for reference purpose only and The Times of India claims no ownership of this content. The Times of India does not support or promote piracy in any manner.Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

BJP eyes Rohtak, Sonipat takeover.description: CHANDIGARH: After making a clean sweep in parliamentary elections, BJP is not only looking at second consecutive term in the state, but is also seriously focusing on Jat-dominated Rohtak and Sonipat districts, considered bastion of former chief minister and senior Congress leader Bhupinder Singh Hooda. Chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar is expected to start his round of meetings from June 21 after attending the International Yoga Day celebrations at Rohtak. On June 25, he has convened the meeting of party MLAs, ministers, chairmen and heads of various boards and corporations at Rohtak. Notably, barring Rohtak and Sonipat parliamentary constituencies, BJP has shown a good presence in parliamentary elections. Bhupinder Hooda and his team holds 11 out of 18 assembly constituencies in Rohtak and Sonipat. The Congress has 16 MLAs. Barring Kiran Choudhary, Randeep Singh Surjewala, Kuldeep and Renuka Bishnoi, all other MLAs are in Hooda's camp and hail from Rohtak, Sonipat and Jhajjar. "We have done well in the entire state. Now in view the results, people in Rohtak and Sonipat too have expressed their keenness for BJP. Hence, we are focusing there as well. Bottomline remains the same that we want to bring dynastic politics to an end. Secondly, BJP has been accepted by all," said CM's media adviser Rajiv Jain. Sources said after Sonipat and Rohtak, Mewat will be the main area of focus for BJP. Some steps including waiver of educational qualification for drivers and other announcements point to party's focus on minority-dominated Mewat. Assault case: Hry Police starts probe ag.description: SIRSA: Olympian and Arjun award-winning boxer Jai Bhagwan, who is an inspector with the Haryana Police and posted as the station house officer (SHO) of Rori police station, has been transferred to Sirsa police lines and a departmental probe initiated against him for allegedly assaulting a hotel manager. A CCTV footage of Jai Bhagwan, in which he is seen assaulting the hotel manager following a dispute over her woman companion’s ID card, has also gone viral. According to the police, Inspector Jai Bhagwan had booked online a room in a hotel in Anaj Mandi area of Sirsa. It is alleged that the inspector reached the hotel with a woman and gave his and her IDs, but hotel manager Virendra Singh said the woman’s ID was fake and demanded a genuine one. Sources said an enraged former boxer beat up the manager and the whole incident was captured in a CCTV there. It is alleged that he also forcibly erased the room booking entry in the register of the hotel with a pen. After the incident, the hotel operators held a meeting and then complained to the superintendent of police (SP) of Sirsa, following which the SP ordered to transfer Jai Bhagwan from Rori police station to Sirsa police lines and also ordered a departmental inquiry against him. DSP Aaryan Chaudhary, who is investigating the case, confirmed that he would start a probe against the Olympian boxer and said that he had been removed from the post of Rori police station SHO and shifted to the police lines. Jai Bhagwan, 34, is a twotime Asian Championship medallist and a bronze winner at the 2010 Commonwealth Games, and also represented India in boxing in the lightweight (60 kg) category at the 2012 London Olympics. He qualified for the London games by reaching the quarter finals of the 2011 World Amateur Boxing Championships in Baku, Azerbaijan. In 2011, he appeared in a reality game show, hosted by Shahrukh Khan, called “Zor Ka Jhatka: Total Wipeout” and was one of the finalists. At the 2012 Summer Olympics, in a dominating performance, he thrashed Andrique Allisop of Seychelles 18-8 in the opening round on July 29, 2012. On August 2 2012, Jai Bhagwan lost to Kazakh fighter Gani Zhailauov at the London Olympics. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Child panel office too gets daycare cent.description: GURUGRAM: A day after a daycare centre was set up at the Mini Secretariat, another was inaugurated at the Child Welfare Committee (CWC) office in Sector 15’s Part 2 on Wednesday. The facility is expected to benefit not only CWC employees but also visitors who come to the office to file complaints along with their children. The centre was inaugurated by additional deputy commissioner Mohammed Imran Raza on Wednesday. The centre will have toys and books for children and a section for feeding babies like the Mini Secretariat daycare centre, which was inaugurated on June 18. Both centres have a woman attendant to look after children up to seven years of age. “This is a very child-friendly space created in our premises. Complainants visit our office with their children. This space will make children comfortable. They can play with toys, read books or draw pictures,” said Shankutala Dhull, chairperson, CWC Gurugram. The centre has been provided with books for children at present, but toys will be provided by June 23. This was the second inauguration of a daycare centre at a government building in Gurugram. A few workers availed the facility at Mini Secretariat on Wednesday after it was opened. Both the daycare centres can accommodate around 25 children each. The district administration plans to improve the facility based on the feedback they receive. A similar centre has been set up in the Sohna judicial complex. PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans. In Video:Govt has taken measures to set up 'chowkidar' in space: PM Narendra Modi in OdishaDownload The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

DTCP to challenge district court\u2019s.description: GURUGRAM: The department of town and country planning (DTCP) has decided to approach the Punjab and Haryana high court against the decision of the district court to de-seal the residential properties, which were sealed by the department for illegally running commercial activities. The district court on June 6 ordered the department to de-seal four out of 13 residential properties in DLF 1 and Golf Course Road which were sealed by the department last month for running illegal commercial activities from residential establishments. After the action, the property owners had approached the district court. Around 30 commercial establishments, being run from five residential buildings on Golf Course Road were sealed last month. The enforcement wing of department of town and country planning (DTCP) swung into action after its director KM Pandurang ordered officials to seal the illegal establishments. Earlier, the planning wing of the department had cancelled occupation certificates of 38 residential buildings situated on Golf Course Road and Sushant Lok 1 after a team of officials found that illegal commercial activities were going on in these buildings. District town planner (enforcement) Ved Prakash Sehrawat said, “The department will file a petition against the district court and ensure that the property owners, who were illegally running commercial activities from residential properties, do not go scot free.” As per rules, commercial activities are not allowed in residential areas, be it licensed colonies that come under DTCP or plots in sectors falling under Haryana Shahari Vikas Pradhikaran (HSVP). Lost phones are no longer a lost cause.description: GURUGRAM: Aanchal, resident of DLF Phase 2, lost her phone in a cab while returning home from office in January. She filed a complaint with police but had never expected to get her phone back. On Monday, she got a call from police asking her to visit the police commissioner office to receive her lost phone. She is not the only one. Across the city, 65 people who had reported losing their mobile phones last year, had their phones tracked down and recovered by police from as far as UP, Bihar, West Bengal and other parts of the country, after months of effort using latest technological tools.  The recovered phones include all leading brands, from iPhone and Samsung to Oppo, OnePlus and Xiaomi. According to police, the total retail value of the recovered phones is around Rs 10 lakh. This was first time when large numbers of phones were traced and returned to owners. Not surprisingly, the owners were overwhelmed to find out that cops had such a service. “My husband and I had never thought we’d find the phone again. It’s great to get it back. Knowing that cops put in so much effort was a true surprise,” said Sakshi Midda, who received her Samsung phone she had lost last year. Every day, around 100-120 cases of lost/snatched phones are registered at different police stations of the city. Most remain untraced, for multiple reasons — lack of technological know-how that can be used to track them down, besides serious crimes that keep the understaffed force busy. Police commissioner Muhammad Akil said different police teams were involved in tracking these phones, adding that they are now trying to set up a special team just for tracking lost and stolen phones. “We’re hoping to hand over recovered phones to people every week,” said Akil. Without elaborating on the methods used, he added the amount of effort needed to recover phones can be understood from the fact that on an average, it took five days for police of two states to recover one particular phone. “The thief had hidden the phone in a box of grain,” said Akil, adding they can’t reveal more about the probe, but stressed that the investigation involved a lot of technical know-how. Elaborating on why police took so much effort to track phones, the police chief said though mobile phones are small items, owners treat them as treasures.  “Today, mobile phones carry all kind of data, including banking details and passwords, personal photographs, videos and even secrets,” said Akil. He said he has directed the cyber cell of Gurugram police to track all lost mobile phones as soon as complaints are registered. “This is a small initiative, but it’s expected to provide relief to a large number of people,” said Akil.
